div1.p: THE TOWN BEFORE YOU, A COMEDY, AS ACTED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: PRINTED BY G. WOODFALL, FOR T. N. LONGMAN, PATERNOSTER-ROW.

div1.head: TO MRS. FRUSHARD, CALCUTTA.
div1.p: I SELDOM write Dedications. Whenever I have written one, it has been from an impulse of veneration, or of tender gratitude. THE BELLE's STRATAGEM I dedicated to her Majesty; THE TOWN BEFORE YOU is dedicated to you.

The virtues which you practise in your elegant pavilions at GASSARY, have
reach'd the British shores. Their reputation now echoes back again to those of the Ganges; and I would persuade myself that I may be the cause of extending it still farther. Yes, I would hope that this humble pen may speak to those of after times, and tell them that you quietly perform such acts of graceful goodness, as open a thousand mouths in your praise, whilst you persuade yourself that all is secret, and that no one finds you out to be more amiable and respected, than the generality of human creatures.

This self deception is a little help'd on, by him, to whom of all earthly beings you are bound to look up. He aids your charming impositions—he assists you in fixing fetters of gratitude on all around you, and then persuades himself and you, that Heaven alone is privy to the deed. But you could not hope always to go on
in this sort of concealment—at length you are unveil'd!
I am unable to measure the extent of my private obligations to you; but may this public acknowledgement of them convince you that they throb in my heart, and that I must be

closer.signed: Ever, MADAM, Your faithfully devoted, H. COWLEY.

div1.head: PREFACE.
div1.p: THE following is rather the Comedy which the Public have chosen it to be, than the Comedy which I intended. Some things have been left out, and some have been added since the first representation: In short, the Comedy has been new class'd—it has been torn from its genus.

It is hoped, however, that there may be found characters, in THE TOWN BEFORE YOU, to interest, and situations to attach; and that those events which were vivacity in the Theatre, will not be dulness in the closet.

But it must be noticed, that the scene, in the second act, between TIPPY and his Landlady, and that in the fifth act, between TIPPY and the Bailiff, were no part of my original design. They were written during the illness of MRS. POPE, after the Piece had been played several nights. Alas! I am sorry to remark, that no scenes in the Comedy (to use the Stage idiom) go off better.

An acute Critic lately said, in one of those assemblies where conversation, though sometimes light, is seldom without meaning, "A Comedy to please, in the present day, must be made, not written." It requires no great expanse of comprehension to perceive the meaning of this dogma; the truth of which I am equally ready to acknowledge, and to deplore: But should it want illustration, it may be found every week in a popular Piece, where a great Actor, holding a sword in his left hand, and making aukward pushes with it, charms the audience infinitely more than he could do, by all the wit and observation which the ingenious Author might have given him; and brings down such applauses, as the bewitching dialogue of CIBBER, and of FARQUHAR pants for in vain!

The patient developement of character, the repeated touches which colour it up to Nature, and swell it into identity and existence (and which gave celebrity to CONGREVE), we have now no relish for. The combinations of interest, the strokes which are meant to reach the heart, we are equally incapable of tasting. LAUGH! LAUGH! LAUGH! is the demand: Not a word must be uttered that looks like instruction, or a sentence which ought to be remembered.

From a Stage, in such a state, it is time to withdraw; but I call on my younger cotemporaries, I invoke the rising generation, to correct a taste which, to be gratified, demands neither genius or intellect;— which asks only a happy knack at inventing TRICK. I adjure them to restore to the Drama SENSE, OBSERVATION,
WIT, LESSON! and to teach our Writers to respect their own talents.

What mother can now lead her daughters to the great National School, THE THEATRE, in the confidence of their receiving either polish or improvement? Should the luckless Bard stumble on a reflection, or a sentiment, the audience yawn, and wait for the next tumble from a chair, or a tripping up of the heels, to put them into attention. Surely I shall be forgiven for satirising myself; I have made such things, and I blush to have made them.

O! GENIUS of a polish'd age, descend!—plant thy banners in our Theatres, and bid ELEGANCE and FEELING take place of the droll and the laugh, which formerly were found only in the Booths of Bartlemy Fair, and were divided between Flocton and Yates! With actors capable of giving force to all that is intellectual, is it not pity to condemn them to such drudgery? THEY are no longer necessary. Let Sadler's Wells and the Circus empty themselves of their performers to furnish our Stage; the expence to Managers will be less, and their business will be carried on better. The UNDERSTANDING, DISCERNMENT, and EDUCATION, which distinguish our modern actors, are useless to them;—strong muscles are in greater repute, and grimace has more powerful attraction.

lg.l: AH! ah! you're here, and comfortably tight?
Well squeez'd and press'd, I see—from left to right.
Waiting the moment when the curtain rises,
Gasping for plots, adventures, and surprises!
Were I a Poet—a Dramatic Wit,
And by the Stage Tarantula were bit,
My Prologue shou'd, as was the good old way,
A word or two upon the subject say;
Hint a loose outline of the scene within,
And let you guess the whole ere we begin.
In present times, the Prologue and its Play,
Are as near kin as Michaelmas and May—
Confin'd, then, not to say a word of that,
I'll tell a story—and I have one pat.
A Boniface of late, placed near his door,
"Good larders here, of genuine wines, rich store."
In gold the gaudy invitation hung,
And to the shifting Zephyrs gently swung.
It chanc'd a traveller, with stomach keen,
Leapt from his Rozinante, tir'd and lean,
'Talk'd of his supper, with an eager air—
Resolved, for once, in no expence to spare;
I'll have stewed carp, he cried, and chicken roast.
And, bring me, of the Burgundy you boast.
Y—e—s, Sir, the staring, curtfying Damsel said,
And, in a trice, the table-cloth was laid.
I am my own man, he adds, in accents bold,
Nor shall I fear, to-night, my household scold;
One hundred miles, betwixt me and my dear—
Odds bobs! her shrill alarum can't reach here!
At length came back the pretty, simpering Kate,
And plac'd—two eggs upon his lonely plate.
Our Traveller amazed, the Landlord call'd,
Host! Host! in angry accents loudly bawl'd;
He came—Where are your ducks, your lobsters, turkey, hare?
"Why, there you have them—in the Bill of Fare;
"There you have game, and fowl, and fish, well drest,
"And neat old Port, to give the whole a zest;
"My house affords no other, Sir, believe me,
"I scorns, I'm sure, to go for to deceive ye."
The guest fatigued, enraged, the Inn forsook,
And the road, slowly, to another took:
There, without promise, all was neat and clean,
His food was wholesome, and his room not mean.
So—not to raise high hopes, we cannot meet,
We trust this night's plain fare is fresh and sweet;
And shou'd you like the dressing, we invite ye,
To come as often as the dish delights ye;
A hearty welcome you will always find,
And to your wills, our Host, and House, resign'd.

body.head: THE TOWN BEFORE YOU, A COMEDY.

div2.head: SCENE I.—A plain Apartment, with a few Books.
div2.stage: FANCOURT sits reading—Mrs. FANCOURT at work at some distance.

sp.speaker: FANCOURT.
sp.p: HOW well those fellows wrote, those antients! How finely they satirize the rich, and what respect they have for virtue in rags! My dear, I will translate the passage—off hand now, d'ye hear, off hand! (rises and reads)

Poliarchus, the rich Athenian, wantoning in gluttony, looks with contempt on the poor Cassander: Cassander reposing on his bed of straw, thanks the Gods that he has health and virtue; and prays to be preserved from the misfortune of being rich, like Poliarchus, whose floors are stained with the wine of drunkenness, and whose silver couch is constantly crowded by physicians.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Are you sure that is a just translation, Mr. Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fancourt.
sp.p: What, Madam, do you doubt my knowledge of Greek! Some people can hardly read English at sight; I can translate at sight, thanks to the milk I suck'd in at Oxford. Doctor Johnson and I, were both Oxford men. —I like to read that old Quiz, he was so fond of us Oxford fellows. But he had too much respect for riches—he liked rich people.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: To say truth, I have a little of his way of thinking. I had never much respect towards those Philosophers who are always throwing sarcasms on the rich—

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: (interrupting) I do maintain, Madam, that the rich are the vilest—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Come, come, Mr. Fancourt, your extravagancies have rendered you poor, and therefore you are always raving thus, and pouring your philipics on people of fortune;—as though vice and folly could only be found in palaces, and virtue in garrets.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Hey day! Why Ma'am—why—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: For my part, I believe there is as much goodness amongst persons of fortune, as amongst the poor—and I do not see why the power of dressing elegantly, and living in well educated society, should debase the heart, or weaken the understanding.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: You do not see! why you are the greatest—the most abominable—upon my soul, you are the most provoking fool that ever—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p:
My dear Sir, I do not doubt it—you have repeated these opinions too often for me not to be convinced of their justice. But really now, between ourselves (rising and laying down her work) as opinion is nothing
without example, I will take the liberty to quote yourself in support of mine.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Me! quote me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Even your great and mighty self! Mr. Fancourt, when I married you, you were not poor—not so poor as you are now; and I think at that time you had no particular vices; but as dissipation has brought poverty upon you, I have observed that by little and little your shallow virtues have disappeared, till—

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: (impatiently) 'Till what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Till you are capable of almost any action that will not endanger your neck. Nay, I no longer mind your threatening looks—I am so convinced of what I have said, that my heart feels horror.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: I'll make it feel something else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: You cannot. All other power over my heart is over; you can afflict it no more! But observe my deduction. I state you to yourself as a proof that poverty is sometimes the source of wickedness; and that squalid wretchedness is as capable of debasing the heart, as affluence and splendor.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Very well, woman! very well! still the noise of that child there— (going to the door) what an odious squaling it keeps!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: It is not easy, Mr. Fancourt, to still the noise of children who are hungry. Though they are the children of the first Mrs. Fancourt, it pierces my heart to hear them— why will you not do something to get bread for them?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
What would you have me do? I was not bred to stand behind a counter, nor
to cry "Chairs to mend" in the streets. You know all that—what did you marry me for?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Alas! because I loved you. The sweetness of your manners disguised the emptiness of your heart, and I romantically thought that poverty could never be an evil, when two hearts fondly shared its difficulties. But now—permit me to ask, why you married me?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Because you had a modicum of a fortune—a score of hundreds: and I had not so many shillings.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: That little modicum might have been a bank, if properly managed, and—

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Pshaw!—stuff! I hate such cant. What do you want?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: A person left this parcel, Sir, and said there was no answer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Such abominable cant! (untying the up parcel) I am as tired of it as I used to be of my Grandmother's spelling through Hannah Glass's Art of Cookery, and I believe in my conscience —the devil! here is gold!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Gold!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Keep off—you are too good, too pure, to want such vile trash. Twenty guineas by Jupiter—ah, ah! (shaking the purse.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Here is a note dropt (takes it up and reads) Accept this purse, Sir, from one who is sorry to see such merit in confined circumstances, and who was charmed with your delicate manner of revealing it.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Who is it signed by?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Robert Floyer.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Robert Floyer, a fine old Welchman, who got himself made Sheriff, then a Knight—those two dignities generally follow, like the Old Bailey and a whipping. I made the old blockhead believe that I was deeply versed in Welch antiquities—that Snowden was once a burning mountain, and that the Ap Morgans and Ap Shoneses were lineally descended from King Priam. You see I know how to turn my wits to account—I can make money, though I can't make shoes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Yes, and you see there is generosity where there is no poverty; and that but for the beneficence of a man of fortune, a rich man, your children to-day wou'd have wanted a dinner.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Psha! what merit is there in the generosity of a rich man! a fellow who takes out a handful of guineas from his store as you would dip a bucket into a well? give me the virtue of the poor man who divides his last shilling—his last two-pence with his friend; who takes his pint of porter from his thirsty lips, and shares it with his poorer neighbour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Ah, here is your poor sister —I will go and receive her—you can now assist her distresses—what pleasure it will give you!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: None of your documents—if she is in distress, let her pawn her superfluities, as other poor people do. (going out.) There is some difference between sharing one's last two-pence with a friend, and one's last twenty guineas. Exit.

div2.stage: Mrs. Fancourt goes out on the opposite side, with an air of abhorrence.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
Buckram.
sp.p: Yes, my lad—Pray which is Sir Robert Floyer's?

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Which is— (bursting into a laugh) What, don't you know Sir Robert's? Why, Sir Robert is as well known in Wales as the Monument in Lunnun, or my Lord Mayor in his gilt coach.

sp.speaker: Buckram.
sp.p: Very likely: But which is his house in this street?

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Why this house to be sure (takes off his hat). Why I live we'en. Pray, Sir, what may be your business we'en?

sp.speaker: Buckram.
sp.p: I am the young lady's staymaker.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Staymaker! (puts on his hat) why, I took you for a curnel, or a coptain, or a great knight belonging to a prince, or some'at of that sort. Why, your coate is amoast the colour of scarlet. Aye, I know why that be —you think to pass for one of those brave fellows who go over sea to fight for their country, and, i'faith, its pity but you shou'd!

sp.speaker: Buckram.
sp.p: Prithee let your young lady know that I am here. I am recommended by Lady Horatia Horton; I work for all the ladies of fine taste in town.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Fine teaste! Dad! we cut this morning for breakfast the finest pork griskin I ever teasted in my life. Come with me down the eary steps, and I'll give ye a bit with fresh mustard that shall put your teaste in tune for the whole day.

div2.head: SCENE—An elegant Apartment (within).
div2.stage: Enter Sir ROBERT, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (looking out). Humphrey! Humphrey! Where can this loitering rascal stay? So you found Mr. Fancourt's house?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; in one of the retired streets near Bloomsbury?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
Well, I am glad I sent him those few guineas. Fancourt seems to be a lad of merit; and when he opened his distresses to me,
he did it in such a delicate, modest way! He is an excellent companion, and he has a pretty taste for antiquities—I like antiquities.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: So I guess'd, Sir, by the vast quantity of old worm-eaten furniture you have at home, which you never make any use of, but to shew to strangers. All from the old castles belonging to your forefathers, Sir, I take it?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Yes, all from my forefathers castles. Hum (aside). My grandfather was the first man of his family who ever went to bed, or got up his own master.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Two or three rooms of precious rotten furniture, Sir, give people a notion of the antiquity of your family (archly).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (aside). I believe the dog has found me out—it was for that very reason I bought it. You may remember, David, the year that I was sheriff—I say that year in which I was high sheriff for the county.—Ho—here comes Humphrey. Enter HUMPHREY. Where have you been, you loitering, west-country booby, these three hours?

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Three hours! Why, Sir, 'tis my belief you wou'd have loitered six hours, if you had seen what I have seen, and heard what I have heard.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: What hast thou seen and heard?

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Why, in my way to Bishopsgate-street, I saw folks go into that old fashioned house, where Gog and and Magog stand up to guard the mince-pies, whilst the Lord Mayor dines.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Guildhall.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Yes, Gilthall—it is all over gilt and finery. So I follow'd a gemman into a great chamber, and there—O, my eyes! there I saw beautiful angels coming down through the clouds, on purpose to hold up the glass candlesticks, thus (stretching out his arm).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (seriously). Gad! I shou'd like to see them.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: And the gemmen were debating. Yes—O! my ears! I heard a city debate, and they called one another Mr. Deputy—and one of them, with a fine red double chin, got up and said, I am sorry to differ from Mr. Deputy (speaking gruffly); but I contend that these innovations bode no good to our constitutions. The hour for dining, since my time, was two; it has been three, four, and six; and I suspect shortly it may be eight— hum! I move, therefore, that a petition be presented to the Lord Mayor—hum— hum—

On which a little squinting gentleman rose, and said (in a shrill quick voice), I support the worthy Deputy who spoke last. These late hours are ruinous to the body corporate. On Lord Mayor's Day we dined so late, that when I went afterwards to Fishmonger's-hall to supper, the turbots were gone, nay, the second course was demolished, the sweetmeats were pocketed, and nothing remained but cheese and pickles.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
You are a pickle! Get out—here is a great lady coming—get out of her way— go! Exit. Humphrey.
Enter Lady CHARLOTTE. What, Madam, is your Ladyship going? Has not my daughter had the honour to see you, Lady Charlotte?

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: Yes; and I have left her with a person of much greater consequence—she is in deep consultation with her milliner. To a girl of eighteen, Sir Robert, a milliner is of as much importance as an aid-du-camp to a general. I knew my distance when she entered, and immediately took leave—Pray, Sir, order my chair (to the first servant, who goes off).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Madam, forgive me, if, before you go, I just plump one question. What do you think of Mr. Conway?

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Think of Mr. Conway? That he has all the advantages which belong to fashion, without its vices. He has certainly some vanity, but more good sense. His friends are well chosen; he admires beauty; he loves goodness; and there is a young lady— (archly) Adieu, Sir Robert! Your anxiety about Mr. Conway I perfectly understand, and I hope you are satisfied. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (bowing repeatedly). What a thing it is to have a lady of quality so familiar with one!
sp.stage: GEORGINA enters hastily, followed by JENNY.
sp.p: Well, Georgina, what now? What now?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O, papa! look at this cap—did you ever see so bewitching a thing?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Pho! you little fool!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Look at this bow—look at the tip of this scarlet feather! Here, Jenny, put it away, with great care.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Care, indeed (aside); it is pity my talents have not better employment than taking care of feathers, and wiping band-boxes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Good bye, papa; I am going to Lady Horatia Horton's. I do love to go there. And what do you think I long to be? I long to be a sculptor!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I don't understand ye.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! Lady Horatia does look so charmingly whilst at her labours; her sweet white hands appear like the very marble she is at work upon.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Did I hear right? At work upon marble?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Bless me! Why did I never tell you before that she is a sculptor? She has a large room full of fine things of her own work. O dear! I wish she wou'd teach me her art; I could spend my life amidst fine statues. But pray, papa, when am I to be presented! I am not in town till I am presented.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Not in town!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Nay, indeed, its true; Lady Charlotte told me so. I can't go any where in public, nor be spoken to by a single creature, till I have been presented: I am not come out till then.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Not come out! Bless me, Georgina, my dear, why then Saint James's has its slang as well as Saint Giles's.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p:
Yes, to be sure it has; and we must make haste and get the slang, or they will
find us out to be mere bumpkins. When shall I be presented?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Have patience. I am come to town about a little business of that sort myself. Perhaps we shall be presented together.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: How, ha, ha, ha! presented together! Was ever such a thing heard of? Miss and her papa presented together! Then did you never come out till now, papa?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Pshaw! mine is quite a different business. If I am put into a great office, I must be presented in course.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Why, what are you going to be?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: That I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: If they give you your choice, pray be a duke. O! how I shou'd doat on your being a duke!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Then I shou'd be a lady—Lady Georgina—delightful! Lady Georgina's name should fly about the town as though it were made with wings to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Nonsense! You a duke's daughter, indeed! A pretty figure you'd make as a duke's daughter!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Figure! Where the difficulty? I can do it exactly—you shall see now—When I was last at Lady Horatia Horton's, a countess from the Opera came in, thus (striding across, and sitting down abruptly) —Bless me, Lady Horatia, how cou'd you be at home to-night? I gallopp'd sixty miles to-day, have kill'd one coach-horse, and spoiled another, merely to hear the Banti—O! the Banti!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: The bantling! why, whose bantling was it!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! her upper tones!—and, O! her under tones! whilst she was flying from B to C, hanging upon G, running into cantabile from E, and sinking down by just gradations to D, the whole house were magnetized—I saw a general faint—a minister of state take out his smelling bottle, and a prince of the blood blew his nose.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Blew his nose! very affecting indeed! and countesses are charming creatures. But, dear Georgina, the warmth of thy imagination would disturb my peace, did not thy extreme giddiness prevent its fastening on any one object for more than ten minutes together. Hah! take care of thyself, my dear Georgina, thou art treading upon men-traps and springguns. Thy paths, though seemingly covered with flowers, are full of thorns, prickles, and adders.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Thorns, prickles, and adders! law, Papa, why people never seem to feel them, and I dare say I shall dance over them as lightly as my neighbours. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Yes, DISSIPATION! thou art the enemy of female honour. It is on thy accursed altar that the peace of the wife, the repose of the husband, and the welfare of whole families, are continually offer'd up. O! shield my child. (lifting up his eyes and hands) from the corruption of DISSIPATION! Exit.

div2.head: SCENE—ASGILL's Lodgings.
div2.stage: CONWAY enters, preceded by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: My master is engaged, Sir, but I will acquaint him that you are here. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Hah, Conway, I saw you come in, so I follow'd you up—I know you are at home in Asgill's lodgings.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Are you acquainted with Mr. Asgill.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: No; notwithstanding he keeps good company, and is nephew to a rich old Sir Simon in the City, who between loans and lumber, makes money faster than he tells lies! but there are an odd sort of three corner'd mortals one can never close with—they present a point at every turn; you may as easily come into contact with a porcupine. I know all the people in town except himself, and I came in on purpose to ask you to make us intimate.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: That will be impossible. Pray Fancourt, how do you get acquainted with every body, for—let me say it in a whisper—your reputation is not of the very first water. (not whispering.)

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Pho! what men are diamonds in the way of reputation? French paste does as well, and one is not so much afraid to damage it. If I were such a fellow as you, with a character of the true water, I should be in eternal anxiety —never dare to turn to the right or the left— fearful of a speck here, of a flaw there; as it is, I brush on through the world—my French paste makes a shew, and if I lose it—why I lose a thing of no value.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Amazing!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
Hang me if I would be troubled with a first rate character, any more than with a first rate beauty—it would only
create envy, and my friends would never rest 'till they had robb'd me of it.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: O! that talents should be thus enlisted in the service of vice.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: That I swear you learnt from our old one-eyed Proctor of Brazen Nose—I remember the very words; I have heard them fifty times whilst I stood on his blind side. O! that a man should thus live on the scraps of others all his life, and never dare coin a principle for himself! So, you won't introduce me to Asgill? (Conway shakes his head) very well —very well—I'll introduce myself to an Archbishop before I am a week older, and get myself made a Prebend in revenge.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Asgill, I am come to disengage myself from the hunt; I cannot be with you tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: Very well—I shall not enquire your reasons; nor shall I pretend to guess that there is a little Welch Diana in the way of the hunt— you have not seen her I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Be not so daring—I have seen her; but I have only seen her. She is as wild as one of the kids on her father's mountains.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: Where have you met with her?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: At Lady Horatio Horton's; but her volatility is so great, that it wou'd be as easy to catch quicksilver.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p:
I cannot say I think so—she does not want life; but it is the sweet pensiveness of her character that charms me—a thousand graces
hang about pensiveness which mere animal spirits destroy.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I have not seen her in that humour.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: And then her fine taste.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Her taste is as fine as other people's I dare swear; but she will bear a little polish.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: She bear polish—ha, ha, ha! where will you find such a mind, such an understanding?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I have no doubt of its native excellence, and I hope to have the pleasure of improving it.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: You! what do you mean, Sir? of whom are you speaking?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Of whom do you speak?

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: Of Lady Horatia Horton—did you not name her?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! so this is confidence by chance! dear Asgill, I have blundered on your secret very undesignedly—I was speaking of the daughter of Sir Robert Floyer.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: But you mentioned Lady Horatia; and the moment her idea is presented to me, every other is swallowed up. O! Conway, she engrosses my whole soul—to see her is bliss, and the sound of her voice is rapture.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Heyday!

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: You have the secret by chance; but you are welcome to it, and I am prepared for all your jests on my passion for a woman who is devoted to sculpture.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p:
Faith, I perceive no room for jests. I think it must be charming to see a fine woman sit with a chissel, and bring out of a block of marble, a form as graceful as her own; every feature glowing with animation beneath
her eye, and every stroke of the mallet warming the cold mass into mind and expression.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: (smiling and catching his hand). I thank you; but your eulogy is not compleat, for the purity of my Horatia chastises the art she loves. The subjects she selects, Delicacy itself would paint out: with an enchanting modesty she seeks for models only in the graces of her own sex, the daughters of Britain, and the matrons of Greece.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Very well: but you are a Son of Britain—does Lady Horatia—

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: (eagerly). Yes—no—I can not tell. She treats me with rigour, yet I think her heart has passion. I sometimes fancy I see it shine like the sun in November—unwillingly, and by starts.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Why do you not lead to an explanation.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: I cannot; for she is rich, and I am as you know, dependent on the will of an Uncle.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: He has the reputation of being a Croesus.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: True; but a fortune, whose basis is commerce, may be doubled, or dissolved in a month.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Well. Pray for me, my dear Asgill, that I may catch my little Welch fawn; I have no prayers to make for you; for I perceive your's is one of those sober passions, that, end as it may, your mind will keep its equilibrium. O! how delightful it must be to love with so much good sense. Exit. laughing.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p:
O! how he mistakes! it is in souls like mine that love rages with all his fury.
The gay, the volatile, can scarcely maintain a passion; but in the serious and reflective mind, love raises a despotic throne, and, like the burning sun of Africa, he pours his chiefest ardors upon slaves.
Perkins! how now! your looks alarm me. What news from the City?

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: O! Sir!

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: My good friend, speak. You very much distress me. Something is amiss.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Would I could say your fears were unfounded. Something is amiss — your Uncle—

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: Nay, speak at once! I can bear any thing rather than suspence.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Then summon all your fortitude! your Uncle, the good Sir Simon, has sent me to tell you that—he—is—undone.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: Oh! (pressing his forehead with his hand) undone! did you say so, Perkins? did you?

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: The misfortunes which have shaken the trade of Europe have at last reached him. He who lately ranked on Change a two hundred thousand pound man, may not, when his creditors are satisfied, be able to command one thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p:
(after a distressful silence). Your news is heavy, very heavy! leave me, dear Perkins! I want to ruminate on my misfortunes alone. Exit. Perkins. (Throws himself into a chair). My worthy, my unhappy Uncle! the tide of affliction must roll
heavy on him. (Arises after a pause). It is determined—I see Lady Horatia no more. No—never more— (sighing deeply) never shall her delicacy be insulted by seeing a beggar court her to his arms. (Walks backwards and forwards). But what can I do? bred to no profession, knowing nothing; ignorant of every art by which independence, or even bread may be obtained; I am thrown a vagabond upon the world. O! my too indulgent Uncle, when you sent me to Cambridge, had you placed me, rather, in a counting-house, I might now have been in a situation to have soften'd all your afflictions—instead of which—O, horror! my soul sickens—my head is dizzy—I sink to death. Goes off reeling.

div2.head: SCENE I.—A Lodging House.
div2.stage: TIPPY walks hastily across the stage, and almost goes off—Mrs. BULLRUSH follows him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bullrush
sp.p: (bawling) Nay, Mr. Tippy— stay, Sir, you shall hear—you shall hear me. (Groans and puts a handkerchief to her mouth.)

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (turning). Shall hear;—why how the devil can I avoid it? a pound of cotton stuff'd into my ears would not keep out the sound—I wonder you can open your mouth so wide, with such a pain in it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bullrush.
sp.p: Aye—between my tooth-ache and you, I am almost mad. Sir, I tell you plainly I do not like your goings on, and I desire you to quit my lodgings.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (chucking her chin). Not for the world; for then I must quit you, my dear, good humoured, quiet Mrs. Bullrush.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bullrush.
sp.p: None of your jeers. I don't like the sort of company you keep (groaning).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: That's odd; for my friends are of all sorts and complexions.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bullrush.
sp.p: And of all characters too, I believe. They seem most of them to be men who live by their wits.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Yes;—I like to have my wits about me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bullrush.
sp.p: And, Sir, you have been in my lodgings fourteen weeks, and I have never yet seen the colour of your money.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: No!—that's a reproach I am asham'd of—you shall make it no more (takes out a purse, and pours gold into his hand). There—bright yellow gold as ever came from the mint—does not the colour charm ye (she attempts to snatch it). Good morning! Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bullrush.
sp.p: Nay, this is too bad—stop— stop! Runs after him with her handkerchief up.

div2.head: SCENE II.—St. James's Street.—the Palace, Fruit Shop, &c.
div2.stage: FANCOURT is discovered in the fruit-shop, talking to the mistress, and eating fruit. He looks through the window.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: The sun always brings out butterflies—a fine shew of women to-day. (Tippy walks across). Tippy—Tippy—hey!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Who is so familiar with my name? (looking round). Hah! Fancourt—I have not seen you these six months—are you engaged there?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: No—I'll come to you.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: The fellow looks as well as ever; I wonder what he's upon now (Fancourt comes from the shop). Well, my boy—how goes the world?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: How goes the world—round, I suppose; for its inhabitants seem all giddy— where have you been since we parted at Bath?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Bath? that was a twelvemonth since. I have been in a thousand shapes, and a thousand places since then. The last was Italy.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Italy! how the devil could you get there? was you bear driver? I mean did you hold the leading strings of some pretty Master, running the tour?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: How I got there you may know hereafter; but there I have been. Zounds, man, I learnt to be a critic there—I talk of statues and intaglios—of busts and medallions—I find fault where ever I go—my judgment is asked—my satire is feared—I am courted and hated—O! its a glorious thing to be a critic.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Why you don't pretend that you are really a connoisseur?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I pretend to any thing that will either get me into a dining parlour, or a wine cellar. I pronounce on Paintings and Tokay—on Statues and Old Hock; I know exactly the grapes from which the one was pressed, and the age in which the other was chissell'd—psha! man, there requires little to be a connoisseur, but impudence.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Well—but how do you live— plainly—how do you eat?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: For the last three months I have eat on the strong likeness I bear to Lord Beechgrove.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: The resemblance is astonishing— they call you his polygraph.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: You are mistaken. They call his Lordship my polygraph.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: I stand corrected. But how have you lived on this resemblance, has he taken you up for the sake of the likeness?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p:
Taken me up! you are curst unlucky in your phrases to-day. No, no—he has been useful to me without his knowledge: for instance, I pass'd one night through Portland Place, and saw a great route. I dash'd into the hall, cursing the crowd of carriages which prevented my chariot from coming up. The porter instantly knew me; gave my name—and LORD
BEECHGROVE resounded all the way up the stairs. The lady of the house received me; placed me immediately at a Loo table, and in two hours I brought off two hundred guineas.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Lucky rascal!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I lately walk'd down to Barnet; took a chaise and four, and bade them whisk me to the Royal Hotel, Pall-Mall. Away we flash'd; roads all mud—horses plunging—post-boys cutting; measured Finchley Common in seventeen minutes, ten seconds. Rode over a smoaking Common Councilman at the Adam and Eve—run in at Tottenham Court Road, and came neatly up (making postillion-like motions).

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: The waiters recognized my Lordship, gave me the best apartments, the very rooms the Turkish Ambassador had, and there I lived in first style; no epicure—never chose more than five things at table; drank Champaigne: in ten days took my leave to visit my Cumberland estate, and ordered the bill to be ready against my return.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Gad, I advise you to take his Lordship up, and swear that he's an impostor—you may then enjoy his Cumberland estate.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I have taken a fancy to an estate in another county; a better scheme, my boy! (slapping him on the shoulder). A plan which sometimes forces me to take shelter, like Hercules, under the disguise of a petticoat. Yes, like him, I exchange my club for a distaff, or like Achilles, transform my surtout to a gauze robe, and my waistcoat to a lace tucker.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
Hah—high examples! Come, tell me—No, defer! defer! here comes a lovely
Welch girl, whose father I sometimes do the honour to call upon.

div2.stage: GEORGINA enters from Pall-mall, followed by HUMPHREY.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! dear Mr. Fancourt, how do you do? Nay, do not stop me. I hate to stand in the street, people stare at one so.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: For that very reason you do not hate to stand in the street. What is beauty good for, if it is not to be looked at?

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (aside). Oh, ho—now I find whereabout you are. I know more of this family than you guess at, mon ami.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Whilst these gentlemen are talking to Miss, I'll step in here for a hap'eth of apples. (goes into the fruit-shop.)

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: How came you here without your carriage?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: It is so charming a morning that I bid it follow me from Pall-mall, where I have been shopping. Nay, I beg you let me pass. Bless me! where is my servant? (looking round) I am going to Lady Horatia Horton's on the most particular business in the world. (Humphrey bursts out of the shop).

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: O! such extortioning! such cheatery!—I never heard the like—I wonder they are not afraid to stand in their shoes.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: What is the matter, Humphrey?

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Miss, as I hope to be—I did but just pop into my mouth a little bit of a peach —'twere no bigger than a walnut—it went down at a gulp like a pill—and they have made me pay a shilling for it.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Why, how could you think of going into such a shop?

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Such a shop! why not? A shop's a shop, if honest people did but keep it, and as free for me as another.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Follow me—I am ashamed of the noise you make. Exit.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: A shilling! Upon my say-so if— aye, I'll mark you, never fear. (following).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: She's a lovely girl! an heiress? I'll pretend ignorance for the present (aside).

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: She is—we'll speak of that hereafter. Her father is coming towards us from the Park. Now her father is a rich old fool, and we are two wits. Folly has been the natural food of wit, since the sun first threw his burning glance upon mankind.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I understand ye—But I'll lend no assistance unless we halve it—remember that— halves or nothing.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Why, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Are you upon honour?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: To the last breath—The old fool —hang it—he is no fool neither. In ten words, for here he comes, he was of use on a late election, and the parliament-man (sneering) advised him to come up to town to receive acknowledgments from the minister. He was afraid to leave his daughter behind, so wisely brought her up. Enter Sir ROBERT FLOYER. (Running towards him.) My dear, Sir, how I rejoice to see you! I call'd at your house to return thanks for the great—

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: O! not a word, not a word, Mr. Fancourt. Silence will oblige me—

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Permit me, Sir Robert, to make you known to my Lord Beechgrove.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
Fancourt.
sp.p: First cousin, and his most particular adviser.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: My Lord, I am your Lordship's very obedient, very humble servant.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Sir Robert, I am rejoiced to see you. We have long look'd for you in town. I have heard you much spoken of at a certain table. We know our friends, Sir Robert. Pray, Mr. Fancourt, bring Sir Robert to dine with me. I am sorry to leave you, but it is a cabinet morning, and the concerns of Europe, you know, must not be neglected. Adieu! Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: That's right—never neglect business. O! I wish all the peers were like this peerless peer. Ay, there he goes into the Palace, I see. Mr. Fancourt, I am prodigiously obliged to you for making me known to his lordship. Is he a man of large fortune?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Yes; but a little out at present. It is amazing what vast sums he has expended for the public. He was just asking me if I knew any honest man who could lend him a thousand pounds. He could have ten times that of the Jews—But he hates the Jews—O! he has never any dealings with the Jews.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
O! I always say, my lord, whatever you do, borrow money of the Christians —always borrow of the Christians. He only wants it for a month, just till quarter-day.
Sir Robert, its an opportunity now—he has amazing interest—a single sentence, whilst he is swallowing a glass of Burgundy, would do your business.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Indeed! Whilst he is swallowing a glass of Burgundy?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: I'll shew you now. This is my glass (holding up his glove, formed like a glass). you shall be the great man; we'll suppose his name to be SNAPPER, and I am Lord Beechgrove. Come, SNAPPER, "here's to the girl we love!" (sips) I say, SNAPPER, we must do something for that Welch knight; he who was sheriff there t'other day—

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (interrupting). High sheriff for the county.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Pardon me! High sheriff for the county (sips). He is the saddest old rascal (Sir Robert stares); he (sips) is the greatest enemy we have in the principality.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (in a passion). Why, Sir, what do you mean? They never had such a friend; I spent more money to favour the cause than I care to own. I was for ever on horseback; there was not a cottager who could influence the sixteenth cousin of a voter, whom I did not entertain; and the fact is, it was solely owing to me—

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
What, do you take me to be such a ninny as to plead your services. You are a mere chicken! Listen. I say, SNAPPER, we must have him on our side (sips). The old scoundrel killed his set of coach greys, and fifteen nags in riding about the country to oppose us (sips). He is a great fool, but he is related to all the ap Morgans, and the ap Shoneses in three counties.
In short, we must have him—so here goes— "the girl we love!" Thus, I swallow the girl, he swallows the hint, and the business is done. Will you lend me the thousand pounds?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I will—I understand; this is what you call kicking a man up stairs.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Only for a month.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Nay, if it is for six weeks. I shall not stand upon a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Thus it is to deal with men of generosity.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Call upon me after dinner. I am hurried just now; our member lives in the next street, and I am going to him; but I'll write a draft on my banker for the thousand pounds against you call. O! I like to oblige a lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Well, now to him who is rich in expedients, of what consequence is being pennyless? Let gross, plodding spirits dig and labour; it is ours to gather the fruit. Exit.

div2.head: SCENE—Lady HORATIA's Drawing-room.
div2.stage: Enter HUMPHREY, with Georgina's dress hanging on his arm; Maid meets him.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Here, I have brought this odd garment for Miss. What is she going to do with it?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Could a body see that fine place they talk about, where Madam makes men and women all in marble.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Perhaps you may get a peep at it. There is company there at present. It is called a school.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: School! Zooks, I am glad to hear great folks go to school. Some of them, mayhap, may larn better manners. Exit.

div2.head: SCENE—A large, elegant Apartment, with various Pieces of Sculpture, Statues, Urns, &c.
div2.stage: Lady CHARLOTTE walks down from the top, viewing the statues.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: This is, indeed, a school! Here are copies of all that is valuable in the art she loves. Ah, the lovely artist herself.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Dear Lady Charlotte, I rejoice to see you. They did not tell me you were here.

sp.speaker: Charlotte.
sp.p: I have been here a long while; delighting myself with your charming works. But how full of labour is the amusement you have chosen?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: I do not find it so.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: So different from fashionable life.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: O! the labour of a fashionable life wou'd kill me; I should sink under it. Chipping marble is playing with feathers compared to that.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
The discipline of a life in fashion is by no means of the mildest sort (smiling). Consider, for instance, the necessary vigils and abstinence of a gamester. It is expedient
that she works hard and lives sparingly; for if she does not keep her spirits perfectly cool, instead of cheating her friend, her friend may cheat herThis reflection is copied, pretty nearly, from the elegant Doctor Horne.. My labours are less and more innocent than hers.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: O! I perceive you will be able to defend yourself.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: In the next place reflect on the toils of a determined beauty. Whether she wakes or sleeps; whatever she does, whereever she goes, it is all with relation to the one great object which engrosses her meditations. After hours wasted, murder'd, in the hard work of the toilette, away she springs! Her wheels thunder rapidly through the streets—she flies from assembly, to assembly. Does the music of the concert fascinate her? No. Does polish'd conversation interest her? No. Some other beauty has been the belle of the evening; her heart has been torn with envy; she returns home; drags off her ornaments in disgust, and throws herself on a sleepless bed in anguish. Are my labours less pardonable than hers?

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: You will be too hard for me in argument, so I drop your statues, to talk of yourself. Something, I see, is wrong. What is it? (tenderly) Come, be explicit— You will not speak! In plain language, when did you see Mr. Asgill?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
Not this week—no—not for a whole week! I will conceal nothing from you. I find now that my tenderness more than equals his. I have no joy left—the chissel
drops from my hand, the marble block is no longer moulded into flesh, my taste has no employment, and my heart is breaking.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: How do you account for his absence?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
Tired with my haughty coldness, he has forsaken me. I die with jealousy and self-reproach. He has found an object more amiable and more tender. I knew he loved me, and I gloried in my conquest.—
"Yet still I tried each fickle art
"Importunate, and vain,
"And whilst his passion touch'd my heart,
"I triumph'd in his pain." O, Asgill! thou art revenged!

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: What hearts we possess! Always too cold, or too feeling. My dear Horatia, stonify your's a little. As you give spirit to marble, transfuse the marble to your heart. See, here is your little Welch friend.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! Lady Horatia! I am so rejoiced! Bless me! you are weeping—what has happened?

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: A favourite goldfinch has happened to die, my dear.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: And last night I lost a Canary bird. I am sure I cried for half an hour. Give me your goldfinch, and we will bury them together. O, dear! and you shall copy them in marble; that will be a sweet task for you. (Lady H. takes her hand, and smiles). You know what I have hurried here for?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: No! Why did not you tell me you wanted to give my form to the statue of Andromache—Andromache mourning for her husband; that you have just began to chip out there, you know. (pointing to a block of marble).

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: I did so; but I am out of spirits to-day.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! I will not be disappointed. Your favourite work will put you in spirits. I have brought a dress for the purpose; Humphrey, bring it in. HUMPHREY enters with the dress, and shews marks of aukward wonder. I shall be sadly mortified if you send me away.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: Come, sit down, Lady Horatia, it will amuse you.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Yes, do; and 'tis very fortunate that I lost my Canary bird. I'll think of that, and then I shall look sad enough for Hector's widow.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Pho! you little chit! Well, stand on the pedestal, and lean on the broken column now, with proper pensiveness and grace.

div2.stage: (Georgina runs up steps behind the pedestal).

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Yes, I will be exactly the thing. (tries to look very melancholy). O! my poor Canary bird!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Come, let us place your drapery in statue like order. (she and Lady Charlotte place the folds). Now, keep steady, and think of your Canary bird.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Mr. Conway.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Mr. Conway.

sp.speaker: Georgina
sp.p: (starting). Dear! Mr. Conway.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Some Gentlemen are with him, and they wish to see the school.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Dear Lady Charlotte, receive them, then—I cannot—I cannot indeed! Exit.

sp.speaker: Georgina
sp.p: (runs down). Gracious! now I think of it, I have a great mind to run up again; I will, I declare, and see what Mr. Conway says to me as a statue.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: A statue—why, surely, you do not expect to impose on him?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O yes, I do—I am sure he will not find me out (runs up). Now, dear Lady Charlotte, just place my veil a little on this side. O! make haste—make haste—I hear them coming.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte
sp.p: (placing the veil). I must gratify you. What a giddy thing you are!

div2.stage: Enter CONWAY, with TIPPY, and three Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Lady Charlotte, you have heard of Mr. Tippy?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p:
Ah, ah, what, this is the place! don't mind me, Ma'am; don't mind me, I am used to run about this town, and correct its follies; 'tis a damn'd good town, that is certain; one
always finds subjects for ridicule! well, what the devil am I to see?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Look around.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I, just warm from the School of Florence; I who have trod the Roman Way; have seen the Baths of Trajan, and the Dog Kennels of Nero, I look at the works of an English artist. Ha, ha, ha! (walking amidst the statues, and observing them thro' a glass).

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Heavens! it is—it is she! ah! how well do you represent yourself: for you are yourself all marble; at least your heart is so. Yes, flinty-hearted charmer! you are ever cold and insensate. O! I could stand and gaze my life away, like Pygmalion, had I, like him, the power to warm my statue into love! what, will you not bless me with one glance. Ah, you act your part too well.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Here is an arm; faith, it would make a very good leg; and this fine Grecian lady is like a Kentish hop-picker!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Critic! come hither; come this way; here is a new subject—has not this the true Grecian character?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: What is this? is this Lady Horatia's chissel? (looking thro' his glass).

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: No—it is by a greater artist.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: An English one, I'll be sworn (looking) Grecian indeed! a mere block-chipper!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Is it ill proportioned?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p:
Pshaw! nonsense! talk of proportions to scale makers and carpenters; the thought is mechanical! a mere wax doll! where are the inflexions? a human figure made on this principle, could never move. Now I will convince
you—nothing like conviction; observe the muscle of this foot!

sp.speaker: Georgina
sp.p: (shrieks). O! do not touch me (leaps down). There, Sir, you see I can move; and I can dance (dancing round him).

div2.stage: (Tippy seats himself, in extreme confusion, on the pedestal).

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: What, Mr. Tippy! the breathing form of beauty a wax doll! the work of a block chipper! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Why, Tippy, how is this? is it the First of April to-day?

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: Accept my smelling bottle; you seem ready to sink.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Who! I am done up as a connoisseur. (starts up, and runs out).

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: Mr. Tippy! Critic! Mr. Tippy! Exit. follow'd by all but Conway and Georgina.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! done up indeed; they pursue him as small birds do a hawk. Angel! (turning to Georgina).

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Why, you were the person whom I wanted to make a fool of—pray follow him.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: How is it possible for me to quit the spot where you—

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I declare, Mr. Conway, I will not hear you; I have told you so twenty times. And as to your kneeling, one finds such things in novels; but no man who really loves, thinks of such fooleries.

sp.speaker: Conway
sp.p: (rising). How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I am sure of it; there was a young man who came down to Glamorganshire from College, and almost broke his heart about me! and he never knelt once.

sp.speaker: Conway
sp.p: (startled). O, roses and carnations! (aside) then—did—how—how, I say, were you sure that he loved you?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: How! O, I was sure of it.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Was he always telling you so?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: He never told me so once. He used to run away from me; and, at last, he had a fever, and in his ravings, he talk'd of no one but me.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Who told you so?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: His sister told me so!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: And did you not pity him?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Yes, I pitied him, because I could not love him.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: O, that saves my life. (aside) And where is he now?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I don't know; but I have heard he is recovered, and makes a very great figure somewhere. They always get over it.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: But if you should not love me, I should die.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Love! I wou'd not love for all the world. Miss Gwatkin was in love once, and she grew as pale as horse-radish. Foolish creature, if she had kept her colour, perhaps the Gentleman would have liked her.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: O! let me teach you to love; I see you are yet as ignorant of it, as—

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: As that fine Mr. Tippy was of sculpture, ha, ha! teach me to love; what, teach me to be wretched, to weep, to be sleepless, to lose my bloom. O! if I ever thought it possible that I could love you, I should hate you beyond all bearing—I would fly from you, and never see you more. Runs off hastily.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: She flies! O happy omen! let her but dread me, and I have advanced one step; if she fears to love me, the business is half compleated. Going off with an air of triumph.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Has not my Nephew been here yet?

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: He was here last night, Sir—I took care that he saw no one but me, and he went away in such distress, that my heart ach'd for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Dear lad!

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Here he comes—here he comes—

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: O! how shall. I speak to him? I have given myself a task that I can hardly bear. Enter ASGILL. My dear boy!

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: O! Sir, what shall I say to you—words cannot utter—

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Come, come, hope the best— perhaps matters may not turn out so badly.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: Yes, I will hope and pray for you. But in the mean time (taking out a folded parchment) my dear Sir, I am ashamed, I blush at such an offering. But it is my all—

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: What, what is it you mean?

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p:
You know I have by inheritance a little land; it is but one hundred pounds a year —O! that it were thousands. In this paper,
Sir, it is made over to you (lays it at his feet). And now (Sir Simon looks astonished, takes up the paper, seems much moved, and turns his back). O! my father! (gushes into tears, and runs out).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: O! stop, stop—my dear Sidney, stop!

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: He has rushed into the street like a flash. Let him go, Sir. Such a moment as this does good to the heart of man. He will be better for this affliction as long as he lives.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: But does he not deserve all my love; all my anxiety; all my care?

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: He does—he does—

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: This Lady Horatia, whom I am told of, must be an angel if she deserves him. I wonder now, Perkins, what effect the news of his poverty will have upon her. I have a good mind to wait upon her myself, to see how she takes it.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Will you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I have no great opinion of these fine ladies. She may be good for something; but in general, I believe, you may take them by the bushel; there is not much choice.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Then will you go yourself, Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Yes, I think I will go; and if I find her worthy my SIDNEY—O! but she cannot be worthy! birth, and beauty and riches are all fine things; but when put into the scale against such innate goodness; such an upright mind; such rectitude of character, it is weighing jewels against dross! Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I.—FANCOURT's.
div2.stage: Enter FANCOURT, singing with a careless air, followed by Mrs. FANCOURT.

sp.l: "To obey your will at any time,
"I am ready—I am ready to resign her."

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Affected pleasantry, Mr. Fancourt, is the poor refuge of an uneasy heart. The conversation which has passed in the next room with Mr. Tippy, I have heard; and I fear you have an action in contemplation which will hereafter give you remorse.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Remorse, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Pray do not think that every thing is to be carried off with a laugh.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Not carried off with a laugh! Let me tell you, my, dear, that as long as you can get the world to laugh with you, you may carry any point you please. Only make wickedness pleasant, and they'll heartily forgive you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: But, Sir, remorse of heart— Do you never feel that?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Oh, exceedingly. Yes, I feel remorse very much, when in any of my—little —odd—excentricities, which you, in your vulgar dialect, call wickednesses, I cannot get the laugh on my side.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: What, then, do the world really laugh at wickednesses?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
O! yes, always, my dear, always— when they do not suffer by it. A man will be
horridly mad if I cheat him of a thousand pounds; but if I swindle his neighbour out of it, he laughs, and says, That Fancourt is a sad, wicked fellow, but he's clever; hang the dog, tho' he does deserve the gallows, I like him after all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Monstrous!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: If one seduces any one's wife, the injured husband rages, but his friend simpers; and when he meets the aggressor he takes him under the arm, and says, "Come, tell us the story."

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: O flagitious! Well, Sir, and a daughter?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: A daughter! O! what—what you heard Tippy just now, did you? You heard what was said about Sir Robert Floyer's daughter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Well, then, my dear, keep silence; for if you do not, I will slit that pretty tongue of your's, and make it chatter double, like a starling's. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Oh, horrible! I cannot contain myself! Here is a plot laid for the bitter anguish of a father, for the ruin of a child! (pausing) I will—that dress—yes, that dress of the Savoyard—I still have it—and in that—

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
Hark ye, woman, lest you should mistake the good humour I have shewn, I tell you, that if you dare to utter—to whisper with the slightest breath, what your impertinent curiosity
has put you in possession of, every misery that I can inflict awaits you! I have a dagger (she starts), not for your body, but for your mind. I have something that shall pierce your spirit, through, and through!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: I tremble at your threats— yet I cannot forbear to bid you remember, that the young woman, whose fortune and peace you design to ruin, is the daughter of the man who, touched by your distresses, sent you yesterday noble relief.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Yesterday is past, and a thousand to-morrows are to come; I must provide for them; my opportunities are few, and my wants are pressing! (heavily and louring)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Fancourt, what say you—is POVERTY the nurse of virtue?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Woman! I cannot argue—Remember! Exit. with a stern air, and shaking his finger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt
sp.p: (after a pause). O! how has necessity hardened his heart! Yes, poverty, thou hast a thousand ills besides thy nakedness and want! But this young creature shall not be its victim. I must try to save her—I feel it a duty, and will not be deterr'd. Exit.

div2.head: SCENE II.—The Room of statues, at Lady HORATIA's.
div2.stage: Enter Sir SIMON ASGILL, followed by a servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p:
Yes, tell your lady, Sir Simon Asgill from the city (walking a little way up, and looking about him). Why, what an odd place this
is! Your servant, Madam (bowing to the figure of a woman). Why, you look as melancholy as the wife of a lame duck just waddled home from the Alley. O! here comes the lady herself. Enter GEORGINA. Lady Horatia Horton, I am your most obedient servant.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Sir, I am— (making a low curtesy) I Lady Horatia—ha, ha, ha! (tittering) I wonder who he is.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Madam, I wait on you on a melancholy occasion.

sp.speaker: Georgina
sp.p: (aside). I'll keep it up. Then, Sir, I wish you had staid away. I hate melancholy. Sir, this is my birth-day. I am this day eighteen years of age, and I will not be made melancholy.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Eighteen years; my nephew is ten years older. A happy age, Madam; the union of youth and manhood! Were I a lady I would never take a boy to guide me through life. Eight and twenty is the age, and that is the age of my nephew.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! And pray, Sir, ha, ha, ha! Now pray, Sir, who is your nephew?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon
sp.p: (aside). How flippant she is! My nephew, Madam—Gad, I don't much like her (aside). My nephew is that unfortunate young man, who has been so long in love with you— Sidney Asgill.

sp.speaker: Georgina
sp.p: (aside). So—I shall have some of Lady Horatia's secrets presently. How I will teize her about Sidney Asgill.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I understand he has possessed your good opinion.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Yes, I admire him exceedingly— I never saw him in my life (tittering).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Then, Madam, it must give you pain to know that he is undone. I am his uncle, on whom he depends; but the misfortunes of trade—In short, Madam, if you will be so generous on account of his great merit as to marry him, you will marry a beggar.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I marry a beggar on account of his great merit—Law, Sir! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Consider, Madam, how he loves you.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: What signifies his love—a beggar! I am sure if my papa shou'd—O, dear! I forget—I am Lady Horatia (aside).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I did not know you had a father.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have a father, and a dear father; and if I should—Pho! I blunder again (aside).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Well, that's not to the point. You say, Madam, you will not marry my nephew, because he's a beggar. You will not marry Sidney Asgill, though he is dying for you.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Certainly I will not. (with a determined air). I am safe in saying that, for I am sure Lady Horatia will not marry a beggar. (aside). I desire I may hear no more of your nephew, Sir; a frightful, ugly, disagreeable, odd tempered mortal! I can't abide him.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p:
Then, Madam, as it wou'd not be civil to correct you, I have a great mind to lay my stick about your ridiculous mummery
here! (in a great passion). You say you will not marry my Nephew?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I do say I will not, Sir, (in a pet). I never will! The winter shall scorch first, and the summer freeze.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Then by—you shall not, hang me if you do! I will look amongst the girls in the City. We have as much beauty, more money, and more goodness east of Temple Bar, than can be found in all the squares west of it. So, Madam, I leave you, I leave you to your follies (pointing to the statuary). Refuse my Nephew! I am glad of it; I am glad of it! he shall have a City girl! I have one in my eye, ten times as handsome as you are—old Simon says so!

div2.stage: Exit. with an air of spite.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Then let him have a City girl, old Simon! ha, ha, ha! law, what a fury he went off in! Enter LADY HORATIA. O! Lady Horatia, I have been so diverted— ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: What has so amused you, my dear?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know all about Sidney Asgill—O! how fly you were, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: You amaze me; where is Sir Simon? (looking round).

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! here has been the queerest old Cit! storming and raving because I would not marry his Nephew.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p:
He took me for you; and he came to tell you that his Nephew was a beggar, and
that he was dying for you, and I know not what stuff.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Is Mr. Asgill dying? (greatly alarmed)

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Do not look so frightened. For love of you—no otherwise dying; but he'll get over it; they always do.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: And does he say Sidney is a beggar?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! yes, he repeated that, as though it was a recommendation. You cannot think what a passion he went away in; for I vowed nothing on earth shou'd make me marry a beggar; and he took me all the while for you, ha, ha, ha! (going, and returning). O! I had forgot; the best of all is, he swears his Nephew shall marry a City beauty, with a great, large, clumsy City fortune.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Marry! marry!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I shou'd like to see the bride. He declares she is twenty times as handsome as I am —I mean, as you are.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: O! you know not what you have done! (going, and returning). And she is very handsome? cruel Georgina! and I shall appear to Sidney Asgill, mean, sordid, detestable! he is in poverty, and will think that I despise him! he—you have undone me! and beautiful too—beautiful and rich—O! I am lost!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Why, what can the matter be? I certainly have done something wrong. But to be sure she will not marry a beggar; and yet I don't know—perhaps she may; one hears for ever of the whims of fine ladies, who sit and contrive what odd thing they shall do, to surprize the town with next. Exit.

div2.head: SCENE III.—A Drawing Room at SIR ROBERT's.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Such an impudent, insolent clown as you are; you to pretend for to talk; you! one who never learnt his horn-book.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Better never larn a horn-book, than such books as you have learnt to read, you trumpery! I tell you, I doant like your goings on, and I'll tell master. You are always filling Miss's head with stuff; and I doant like many things as I do see.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: You see! you don't know what you see.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Doant I? yes, I do, and what I hear too. I yeard a fine tale of you in Wales— yes, yes, it is not for nothing that you are drawn forth in your silk gowns, and all this fine rufflety-tufflety; and going half naked, as though you were a lady of fashion. D'ye remember the Coptain who used to come on pretence of admiring the old tattered velvet furniture, that came out of my master's great grandfather's castle, three hundred years ago?—

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
Heyday! Humphrey and Jenny run off frightened. Quarrelling about my tattered velvet furniture! I am proud of those rags: the rags of a man's ancestry ought to be dear to him. I would
give fifty acres for the rags of the old doublet of that ancestor of mine, who came over with the Ambassador of King Priam.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: I am sorry you interrupted them; I like those children of nature; I am fond of natural characters; no disguise—all open honesty—what their hearts prompt, their tongues utter.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: True, Sir, true: I am glad you like plainness; and therefore tell you, Mr. Fancourt, that the draft I promised you for my Lord Beechgrove, I have altered my mind about.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (astonished). Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: All that affair about Mr. Snapper was very pleasant to be sure; but I have met with a thing that has stagger'd me a good deal.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (aside). The devil! staggered, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; I do not understand a man's wanting favours, and then treating those ill who would do them service.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: My very heart shrivels like scorched parchment (aside). Treat you ill, Sir! who has dared to accuse me of treating you ill, Sir Robert? I defy the man; I defy the human being. Whu! I wish I was out of the house

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
Dear, Mr. Fancourt, I have not the least suspicion that you wou'd use me ill. I believe it to be impossible. No, Sir, it is my Lord Beechgrove of whom I complain. Why, Sir, do you know I met him in the Park, and he would not speak to me! would scarcely return my bow! tho' an hour before
he invited me to visit him, as you know. Bless me! what's the matter, Mr. Fancourt.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: O! Sir Robert, I am seized with a vertigo, which is sometimes very troublesome (smothering a laugh). If I had a glass of hartshorn and water—

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Here—Thomas—Humphrey— I'll go myself. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! he has seen the real Lord Beechgrove. O! my back cracks like an old wainscot. The thousand is gone like last year's moonshire, if I can't— TIPPY enters. O! you devil, out of the house!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: What has happen'd?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: What has happen'd! why old Taffy has seen—out of the house—do not stay to ask questions; he has seen your polygraph— out—out—here he comes! (Tippy vanishes). SIR ROBERT enters, follow'd by a Servant with a glass. O! this will be too much for me, I fear, at last. Sir Robert you are very good (drinks). O! bless me every spring and fail! I am better now. You were pleased to say something, Sir, about my friend, Lord Beechgrove. O! I remember now—he met you, and did not recollect you.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: That was very odd tho'! and I said—says I— My Lord, the thousand pounds which Mr. Fancourt spoke to me of—

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Did you—did you? (coughs and laughs with his back turned). Well, Sir Robert, and what said my Lord?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Never a word—never a word. Stared as though I had been a new caught monster. I had not changed my dress, though he had changed his. The difference of dress made me almost think once, that I might be mistaken; but on looking again, I was sure of my man.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Aye—pray what was his dress, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Regimentals.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Regimentals? a hint! (significantly aside) O! he had his regimentals on—aye—he is a Colonel in the Guards. Rather odd not speaking, I confess; but a man, whose head is stuff'd with the business of all Europe, must be forgiven if a slight acquaintance slips out of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why, I can make allowances, Mr. Fancourt; I remember myself, when I was High Sheriff for the county, I once passed an acqaintance, but I made him an apology; and, Sir, I shall expect an apology from my Lord, for not returning my bow, before I advance the thousand pounds. A thousand pounds is money, Mr. Fancourt.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
It is—it is, Sir, and the man who will not make a bow for a thousand pounds, ought never to possess a thousand pence (laughs aside). I will go, Sir, and bring his Lordship here (going). He dines to-day at the Dutchess's in his own square; but I'll engage to bring him away in spite of wit, and beauty, and champaigne.
I'll be a match for thee yet, old Taffy! (aside).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I wish my Lord wou'd invite me to dine at a Dutchess's. I never did dine with a Dutchess. It must be very delightful! I should go back to Glamorganshire, and be able to amuse my neighbours with all her Grace's bons mots, and repeat her Grace's toasts; I would hold my ass-skin slily under the table, and pencil down her good things. 'Tis all the fashion now. Many a man gets a dinner by being known to write down the wit of his host or hostess; tho', after long watching, he frequently brings away empty tablets. Exit.

div2.stage: GEORGINA enters laughing audibly, followed by JENNY.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Aye, Miss, you may laugh, but for my part, I doesn't see any thing in your alablaster statutes—all of one colour, like a duck's egg. Give me a fine large picture, with robes of red, and blue, and rich damask cartains.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Your taste is excellent! (continuing to laugh).

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: But if you talk of statuary, go to Mrs. Silvertip's.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Who is she?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why, a lady who makes the finest statutes in the world, all in wax. There are generals,— and sailors — and princesses — and dukes—and old women, more natural than life. Now if I can raise her curiosity to go there, Jack's business is done (aside).

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Dear Jenny, how can I see them?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why, by going to her Exhibition on Fish-street-hill.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Fish-street-hill—where is that?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Hang me if I know (aside). O! Miss, every body knows where that is. 'Tis just by Grosvenor Square.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I wonder if she wou'd teach me her art?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Yes, to be sure she wou'd. All arts are to be learnt by those who have money, except the art of being happy.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Then the first use I would make of it, should be to imitate the features of Mr. Conway in wax. I then shou'd be able to look at him without blushing, and even talk to him without his being a bit the wiser.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Mr. Conway, indeed! (aside, petulantly).

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O dear! yes I will, I will learn the art. I know his countenance so well, that I shou'd be able to copy it without ever seeing him more. And yet there is one look, which no art can imitate! (tenderly).

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Devil take him! (aside). Well, Miss, I'll carry you there to-morrow. But Sir Robert must not know it.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O not for the world! I will go— I will go—I will go. Runs off.
