sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Yes, so you shall; but Mr. Conway shall never be the better for it. You have a large fortune, my dear, and are handsome; my brother is handsome, and has no fortune—the best reason for to bring you together.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Where is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Just gone to her dressing-room, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Then I'll go and hear her on the harp a little. She has a sweet finger; aye— and she is a sweet girl; but my heart has a thousand aches about her, and dearly as I love her, I am ready sometimes to exclaim with the old song, "I wonder any man alive, would ever have a daughter."

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: O! you old— if you'd had wit enough for to have put a proper value on my charms, I would have taken every care about your daughter off your hands;—but I'll be revenged for all your tricks! here I have been spending anxious days, and sleepless nights, for two years;—making up the smartest caps of wash'd gauze and dyed ribbons;—buying new braids of hair, of a nice nut brown—and all without being able to touch the old goose, any more than if his heart was made of leather. But I'll match you! since you will not make me your wife, I'll give your daughter a husband; and if you should die of the mortification, I know where to find a place to dance on. Exit.

div2.head: SCENE IV.—ASGILL's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p:
O! 'tis in vain! never, Conway, will I sue for compassion from a proud beauty, who
treated me with haughtiness, even when she believed me heir to prosperity.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Pride and loveliness ought to go together. I dislike the vulgar railing against the haughtiness of conscious beauty. She, who over values herself, will never sink too low; and the lady of whom we speak, perhaps loves you.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: For that very reason, I will not again appear before her. I am too proud to raise a conflict in her bosom between her pride, and her tenderness, and to owe at length, perhaps, to her compassion, the acceptance to which her love would never have acceded.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: You are very nice. If my heart were not pre-occupied, and so fine a woman had an inclination to make me master of herself and fortune, I would not quarrel with her about the motive; I wou'd thank the pretty creature, and give her all the love I could.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: Yes; but you are a man of fortune. By this time, I suppose, people begin to talk of my distress'd state.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I have heard it mentioned.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: What has been said?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: A lady observed, that it was pity a man so handsome shou'd be sunk so low; and her husband said he was sorry, because you were such a good kind of young man.

sp.speaker: Asgill
sp.p:
(with contempt). Good kind of young man! I am sorry I have incurr'd such an approbation. (Conway seems surprised) No, no, do not imagine (smiling) that I wish for the reputation of a bad heart. But the term, "Good kind of young man," in our days, is so
applied, that I desire not to be honoured with it. An idle fellow, who hangs loose on society, without merit or avocation, or one who corrupts the sister of his friend, or runs away with his daughter, or does all those things which mankind ought to execrate, is said, in excuse, to be a good kind of young man. In short, good kind of young man, in the present acceptance, may very fairly be translated scoundrel.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, here is the person you ordered from Tower-hill. Slopseller, I think he calls himself. Exit.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Slopseller! How do you translate that? Apothecary, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! No, I assure you. A Tower-hill slopseller does not deal in emulsions and syrups, he—but you must excuse my telling you what he deals in. (growing grave) My dear Conway, adieu! Often think of me, and speak of me as I deserve; but be sure you never suffer people to call me a good kind of young man.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Asgill, though there is some pleasantry in your manner, there is also a seriousness which shocks me. What are you going to do?

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: What I ought to do. What, do you imagine I intend to stay at home, to parade Bond-street, and make the circle of Piccadilly, Saint James's-street, and Pall-mall? No, no, my burning brain cannot be cooled by such expedients; 'tis only the powerful voice of my country can regulate its distraction—Ask no questions—my resolution is fixed—Farewell!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: What! and is the frenzy of your brain regulated by the hope of serving your country? Do all your private woes sink before that powerful principle! O! glorious effect of patriotic love! Every selfish feeling vanishes—to tear myself from you becomes a DUTY. I go—despise not this weakness—I venerate, I pity you! Exit.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: Friend of my heart! He goes in tears! Oh! the drops which manly friendship forces from the eye, are more precious than those collected in the groves of rich Arabia— They sink into my heart—they cherish it!— Now come in, Sir. Enter a Man, with a bundle. Have you brought what I ordered?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes; here are the things, Sir. (opens the bundle)

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: This, then, is the complete dress of an English sailor?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Complete! (opening and displaying it)

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: O! the sight of it warms my heart! In this dress what heroes have bled—what gallant acts have been atchieved! Those who have worn it, have given England all her glory—have given her the boundless empire of the ocean.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, it was your Raleighs, and your Drakes, and your Boscawens who did all that.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p:
O! whilst our grateful retrospection twines laurels around the heroes of departed days, let us not forget what is due to those of our own! Let us look with gratitude towards a HOWE, and hang, with tributary tears, over
the names of MONTAGUE, HARVEY, and HUTT!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ah! the three last are gone.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: But some remain. There only wants occasion, and other Montagues, and other Harveys will start out like meteors, and glide along the British sky, blazing in glory!

div2.stage: (Goes out, pressing the bundle to him.)

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Gad! he's a fine fellow, and will make a noble sailor; but our fleets, thank heaven, are full of such. Exit.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p: There are still two bills unpaid—go and discharge them. That purse contains sufficient. Exit Servant. Now, all my debts paid, and a few guineas in my pocket, I quit my country; but I quit her, to serve her! O! may the boundless blessings of heaven descend upon her; may my arm contribute to restore peace to her; and may GLORY and MONARCHY be hers, till time shall be no more! Exit.

div2.head: SCENE I.—Lady HORATIA's Drawing-room.
div2.stage: She enters with rapidity and disorder, then turns, and speaks.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Yes—order the horses instantly—and yet —no—I shall not want them— Go to his uncle in the city! How strange that will be! But can I hesitate on decorums, when EXISTENCE is at stake? Can I suffer Sidney Asgill to believe that Georgina's fooleries are my sentiments? Can I suffer another to have the transport of lifting him from poverty, whilst I am despised! The thought breaks my heart-strings! Ah! Mr. Conway!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I flew the moment I received your commands.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: My commands! Sir, I only sent to ask—it was only with an intention to — (much confused.)

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Speak, Lady Horatia. (a pause) Do me the honour to repose confidence in me.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I believe I can— I believe I ought—but shame weighs down my very soul. In one moment what will you think of me?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: What I have always thought, that you are one of the first of your sex.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (walks a little way in extreme agitation, then returns). I must speak, for the conflict is too great for me to endure. You are the friend of Asgill—the friend of his youth—the chosen of his heart. (he bows) — Permit me to then to ask, even though your answer shou'd be a breach of confidence, did you ever hear him mention any other lady as one —as one—with whom he wished to unite his fate?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: O never! You are the object of his adoration.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: (with quickness) Then find him out—pursue him! What have I said? My soul shrinks at the sound of the words I have uttered.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Would my Asgill's ears could have received them! Go on, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia,
sp.p: Go on! Alas! need I add another sentence! You see that—humble me not too far—I am proud—Had Asgill continued the heir of splendid possessions, perhaps my pride and coldness would never have abated; but he is poor; he is undone!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Peerless woman!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: My fortune is his—my heart —my soul!

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: O! suffer me to kneel for him! For him I thank you, adorable, transcendent woman!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
I feel your kindness in endeavouring to abate my confusion. The step I have taken I shou'd yesterday have thought less easy than to die. Permit me to leave you, nor dare to think (with resumed dignity) that, because my passion is strong, my conduct shall be
weak! My reputation is in your hands— preserve it as you wou'd your own life and honour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I accept the glorious deposit, and I will deserve the trust. What grace can dignity of soul bestow! The very conduct which from a vulgar mind would disgust, from such elegance and virtue becomes fascinating. Now, Asgill, I will dare to seek thee; and I will pour such transport on thy heart, as shall make thee confess, the hour of thy poverty the most blessed of thy life. Exit.

div2.head: SCENE II—Sir ROBERT FLOYER's Library.
div2.stage: Enter Sir ROBERT in a hurry, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Bring up his lordship and Mr. Fancourt directly—fly down—never keep a lord in waiting. Exit Servant. (Sits.) No, I won't receive his lordship sitting (rises), that will look like want of respect. I will be standing. No—that will not be the thing neither; for then I shall have no opportunity to shew my veneration, by rising at his entrance. No—I must sit, and—Yes, there I've hit it—I'll be reading—deeply employed in reading. Then, when the great man enters, start up, and dash away the book. Let me see—it shall be a large book. I'll get up and reach one down. (mounts the library steps, and takes down a book) —Chambers's Dictionary—that will do. (Takes down another) "The Fall of the Roman Empire." Bless me—my lord!

div2.stage:
(A servant announces Lord Beechgrove. Sir Robert looking round sees Tippy enter, dressed as
Lord Beechgrove, followed by Fancourt. In his fright he tumbles with the books from the steps. They help him up.)

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: O, dear! I am quite confounded. My lord, I beg your lordship's pardon a million of times. Mr. Fancourt—O, my knee! (rubs it) Reach his lordship a chair. A most untoward accident, my lord; but pray accept it as an omen. You found me sprawling at your feet—it shews how devoted I am to your service.

sp.speaker: Tippy,
sp.p: Sir Robert, I have often heard of the politeness of the Welch gentlemen, and you really confirm all that has been said. The year in which you were sheriff, Sir Robert, was such a year of splendour and magnificence, as Glamorganshire will long remember. We heard a vast deal of it at Saint James's; it amused the Royal Circle for a month.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why, my lord, I did my best on that occasion. When I was high sheriff for the county, I neither spared myself or my purse. A hanging in the morning, and an assembly at night; giving the judges a dinner to-day, and to-morrow consulting Jack Ketch about a new gallows. Such a variety of business, my lord, demands a man's whole attention.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p:
Certainly, certainly. A little thing happened this morning, Sir Robert, which has given me pain. You addressed me in the Park, I really was, at that moment, throwing over in my mind the compact between Russia and Poland. In short, I had almost determined to go to Saint Petersburgh, ambassador myself; for I think one or two points might be revised. At that very moment, Sir Robert, just as I was
delivering my credentials to the Empress, and receiving one of those delicious smiles, which—

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: You will go too far. (twitching him)

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I say, just then, Sir Robert, you addressed me.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: No wonder, my lord, that you overlooked me; I am ashamed to have made a complaint of such a trifle.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Pray, my lord, examine Sir Robert's shelves; you will find them well stocked.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: All dead stock, my lord; heavy dead stock.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, pardon me! Such stock is never dead. You have here in calf's-skin and sheep's-skin, the very souls of the authors. Well chosen, I dare say.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why, my lord, as to the choice, I left that to my broker. He furnished the whole house, from the kitchen to the garret; the pots and the poets; the frying-pans and the philosophers were all of his choosing.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Now, Sir Robert, if you would do the thing genteely, write the draft without his observing it, and I'll present it to him after we have left the house. Great men must not have services tendered them coarsely.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I understand you; there is a nice way of doing things. Pray, my lord, amuse yourself with a folio or two. A certain delicate—it shall be so. (goes and writes)

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (taking up a book). "The debates of Leadenhall-street." Pleasant reading—light— pretty reading in a heavy morning!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Leadenhall-street—A thought strikes me.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Then strike again.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: I say, my lord, as Sir Robert is a liberal man, and fond of patronage, suppose you give him, by way of outset, a place at the Board of Controul for Indian affairs, just till a better thing offers. (Sir Robert writes, and listens by turns).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: The thought was too obvious to be missed—exactly suits his discernment and spirit. (whispers, then speaks audibly) The nabobs (whispers) —the begums (whispers) —muslins, alaballas, mul-muls, and nansooks (whispers), Nankeen china (whispers), Patna rice (whispers).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (runs up). O, my lord! my lord! (slides the draft into Fancourt's hands) Not a word—mum! (his finger to his lip)

div2.stage: (Fancourt holds up the draft to catch Tippy's eye.)

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Faith, I had better go about it directly—no time to be lost—let us finish the business at once. (looking significantly at Fancourt) Sir Robert, your servant.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Sir Robert, your servant. (both hurrying off)

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (stands and stares). "Sir Robert, your servant"—mighty short! Well, but they're in a hurry to serve me—a little rudeness, when it proceeds from kindness, may be pardoned.

div2.stage: Enter GEORGINA hastily, followed by JENNY.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! dear papa, there is a woman in the square with some odd music; I am going to the bow-window to hear her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Get along, madcap! (going) begums, nabobs, Patna rice—Sir Robert, your servant—mighty short! Exit.

div2.head: SCENE III.—The square.
div2.stage: Mrs. FANCOURT, dressed as a Savoyard, enters, winding a hurdy gurdy, attended by two children, the one with a tambour, the other with a cymbal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p:
This is the house; here will I place myself—fortunately I may attract the lovely victim. (sings and plays)
I be von poor Savoyard,
Get but lit, and labour hard;
Wet and cold me oft' endure,
Patience be my only cure.
GEORGINA appears, JENNY stands behind her.
Ah, Ah, charmante lady, cast down your bright eye,
Compassionate look, or perhaps I be die;
I see von sweet smile stealing over your face,
It give you new beauty, it give you new grace,
I be von poor Savoyard,
Get but lit, and labour hard;
Wet and cold me oft endure,
Patience be my only cure.
Make von curtesy to de lady, you lit impudent ting.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Do not chide her. Where did you come from?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: From von great vay off; I live among de mountains, and I be come to make please de prit lady of dis country. (Georgina throws down silver.) Take up l'argent, ma petite, and put it in votre poche—Bless your charité. Lady, I can tell de fortune by looking at de vite hand.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Can you? O! dear Jenny, let us have her up.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Laws, Miss, don't let such creatures come in; they may steal something; there's a wicked look in her eyes; I understand eyes as well as she does hands.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Dat prit young voman's by your side, lady, be born to von great luck— she vill ave de grande offer.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Well, Miss, if you will have her in— I'll go and open the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Thus far I am successful. O! horrid! that such youth and goodness should become the prey of two villains! Ah! the door opens.

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: (opening the door). Come, come—make haste. They enter.

div2.head: SCENE—Changes to the Drawing-room.
div2.stage: GEORGINA enters, followed by Mrs. FANCOURT and JENNY.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Come, let me look at your prit vite hand. (takes Georgina's hand, and pretends to examine the lines.) Ah, I see—I see— But I ave not de power to tell de fortune before any von—dat gentle—sweet temper young vomans must go.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Go, Jenny, d'ye hear? Leave the room; go directly.

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: (going reluctantly). I shou'd not have thought of that foreign woman's impudence, to have me sent out of the room—I don't like her—I'll listen, I am determined. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Now, Miss, me vill tell you —you be born to be ver happy, if you be ver good.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Dear! Do you think I am not good?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Bau! Bau! dere be von— two vicked mens, who ave de vicked design upon you—Il faut, you must not see gentlemens, but in de presence of your papa. Your papa be your bon friend.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I never heard any thing so ridiculous. Never see gentlemen, but in my papa's presence. O! you are a fine fortune-teller! Good-day (going).

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt
sp.p: (is agitated; follows, and seizes her). Madam, if you would not be lost beyond redemption, observe what I have said. Two villains have laid such a train—

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Amazing! Why, you now speak good English.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Hah! I had forgot; but when the heart feels it is hard to dissemble. You have detected me. Charming young woman, slight not the cautions which I wear this disguise to give! Surely they must have weight with you, when I tell you, that it is perhaps at the hazard of my life, that I appear before you.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: You freeze me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p:
Treat not lightly then the advice of one, who runs such risks to press it
upon you—I know not exactly what is designed —I have awakened your caution, and my duty is compleat.

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: (running in). Get out of the house, you impostor—you deceiving jezabel. If you do not go this minute, I will order the footman to sweep you out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Young lady think upon my words. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Think upon her words—a vagabond! did you ever see such assurance, Miss? I have a great mind to beat her hurdy-gurdy about her ears.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Be silent! what I have heard shall sink into my heart. I will be circumspect (walking slowly and gravely off).

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Here's a pretty kettle of fish! who can that vile woman be? Jack has let somebody into our secret, who has betrayed us. What labour it will cost me to throw her off her guard! but I'll try (takes a letter from her pocket, and looks it over). Yes, yes; this letter will bring Jack. Hang me, if I don't believe I have spelt disguise wrong. Well, no matter—the meaning is undisguised enough (wafers the letter). Here Humphrey! (smiling, and speaking very gently) Humphrey!
Come, none of your flummery.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p:
Nay, don't be cross—you know we have made it up—here, take this letter, and carry it to my brother Jack. Come now, (coaxingly) you know I am working you the
corners of a new handkerchief, twenty times as pretty as this (touching that which he wears).

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Shall I have it by Friday, when I go to Bob's wedding?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: You shall. (bell rings)

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Well, give it me (snatching the letter). The old place, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the old place (bell again). Hang the bell—go directly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: The wafer's wet, ha, ha, ha! now she thinks I can't read wroiting—help her sappy head! ha, ha, ha! I can read and wroite too, but that's a secret between me and my ownself (looking at it all round). I would not break a seal for the world—for that I know would be a most unhonorable thing; but as to a chambermaid's wet wafer—there—it opens like a boil'd oyster.

'Tis a dainty scrawl. The lines run as straight as the zig-zag of a screw. (reads) "LovingBrother,"—well that's koind— "cum here to-morrow in your old disguise—I mean the (spelling) f—e—m—fem. (looking earnestly) f—e, fe. M. by itself M." Yes, it is female— "and call yourself, as before, Miss Sally Martin." So, so! then that strapping wench that I have let in sometimes, is all the while her brother Jack. (scratches his head, and reads again) "There's something in the wind—we must make short work—be sure you come— your affectionate sister, Jane."

So Jack and Jane are a pretty pair; now, what can they be upon? that's nothing to I— I think I won't carry it—yes, (looks at the corners of his handkerchief) yes, I think I will—I
will carry it—I will see Jack in petticoats once more. Exit.

div2.head: SCENE V.—St. James's Park.
div2.stage: TIPPY walking backwards and forwards with an air of great uneasiness—FANCOURT appears.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (running towards him) O! you are come (breathless). I have been waiting here these two hours. I began to fear that you were slippery —that you were upon your tricks.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: What, with each other? O fye! never. I drove to the banker's and back as fast as the horses of a wretched hack could carry me. In my way I met a fellow in his chariot, who two years since borrowed money of me for shoes.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I never shall meet such a fellow, for I never lend—make a point of that. Come, give me the money—my moiety of the thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (unwilling). Directly—directly— ha! how d'ye do? (bowing to those suppos'd to be passing). Here is the— (puts his hand slowly in his pocket). Ha! I saw you last night (to others) a full concert. I shall be at the tennis-court presently (running off towards the top).

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (following). Rot the tennis-court! give me the notes.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: The notes! well, there are the notes.

div2.stage: (Tippy looks at the notes astonished, and at Fancourt by turns).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Well, what are these?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: What are they? why, the notes— your share of the thousand pounds procured by me this morning (carelessly).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Here are five notes, five and twenty pounds each.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: What, can't you reckon? four notes, five and twenty pounds each, make one hundred—one hundred pounds, principal money. Dear Tippy, do not look so thunderstruck—you are very welcome. I confess I had some thoughts of making it fifty; but recollecting our antient friendship, when I bought into the four per cents. with the rest, I reserved a whole hundred for you. Good day, Tippy.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (seizing him). Stay, Sir—stay you shall (fiercely).

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Nay, my good fellow, do not make an uproar in the Park; because you know if you do, Tippy, I shall be under the necessity of relating some little anecdotes of you, which may end in a procession to Newgate.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (trembling with passion). So, you have bought nine hundred pounds stock?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: And you are determined I shall touch but one.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Only one, Tippy.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (smothering rage). Very well—very well.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (in a passion). Zounds! what wou'd the man have? an hundred pounds for only just walking into an old sprawling fellow's library —and—the devil!—he's here—I'm off!— (runs off).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Is he? he is—no, I'll not run—he's coming towards me—I'll not flinch. Now you shall see, Mr. Fancourt, what it is to use a brother rascal ill. Is not the world wide enough for our tricks, but we must cheat one another? I'll sacrifice myself rather than not be revenged. (Takes out his pocket book and pencil, seeming very intent).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Hah! there's his Lordship—he seems very busy—perhaps I had better pass on —no, I won't—surely, after such a favour— Hah! my Lord, your most obedient. (Tippy looks at him, gazes, then continues to write). Well now I declare (looks amazed). My Lord, I say, your most obedient.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, who are you?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I am astonished!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Who, I say, are you; who thus, twice have taken the freedom to address me in public?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Who am I? what, does not your Lordship know me now? O! perhaps the delicious smiles of the Empress are in your Lordship's head again—perhaps the Polish treaty— perhaps—

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (in a feigned passion). Perhaps neither of these! I am engrossed by your impertinence. Who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Who am I? why, the man who, two hours since, lent you a thousand pounds, principal money, to keep you from the gripe of the Jews.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: A thousand pounds. Eh, eh! (looking very gravely). Lent me a thousand pounds! Sir, (seizing his hand) I am full of concern for you—I see you have been imposed on. Sir, there is a fellow about this town so like me, that we might play the two Socias, or the two Dromios, or pass for two brown russetans growing on the same twig. He resembles my person; he imitates my very dress—Sir, depend on it, he has also assumed my name, and has swindled you out of one thousand pounds, principal money.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, I am thunder-struck. Then, what you said to me this morning—I mean what he said, concerning the Begums, and the Nansooks—

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Was all to cozen you, depend on't. You are cheated, I see clearly. Sorry for you —can't stay—clearly cheated, Sir, depend on't (going).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (much agitated). My Lord—my Lord, grant me a moment—permit me to ask one question—do you know Mr. Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (with scorn). Do I know Mr. Fancourt, Sir! there are a sort of people one may be said to know, because one meets them every where. But as to Mr. Fancourt, why, Sir, I would not keep a groom who was acquainted with such a —such a person.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: If you want to find his character, you will hear of it in Bow-street; if you want to find his lodgings, you must go to St. Giles's. Do I know Mr. Fancourt indeed! Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
Is it ground I stand upon? I am amazed—never were two men so alike on earth.
The look—the voice—the dress—but can Fancourt be a villain? no, it is not possible; to me he cannot be a villain—yet—I know not what to conjecture. Ente FANCOURT behind, grinning, and claps him on the shoulder. (Turns and gazes on him). No—his looks are innocent—it is not possible that he can be guilty.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: How d'ye do, Knight? how d'ye do?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Yet I'll try him (looks sternly). Sir, I have seen a man who tells me you are a villain.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: 'Tis well he does not let me see him. But who is the man—who is he, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Lord Beechgrove—the real Lord Beechgrove, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Hell and ten thousand furies! (aside) explain, Sir, explain! I really cannot possibly comprehend you.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: He tells me, Sir, that the man you brought to me to-day, is an impostor, and that in concert with him, you have cheated me of a thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: How, Sir, an impostor! (in a rage) but I'll be cool—I'll be cool—where was you told of this—where, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: On this very spot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (aside). Hah! I begin to smoke— what, Lord Beechgrove has just left you then?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: This moment—I found him here.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p:
So, this is Tippy's damn'd revenge! (aside) ha, ha, ha! O what a—ha, ha,
ha! what a droll dog! why, Sir, do you not know that my noble friend is the greatest joker in England? ha, ha, ha! I suppose he might tell you there was a man about town who resembled him?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: He did—he did sure enough— he said they were as like as two drums.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he plays those tricks continually—he is inexhaustible as a joker. O! the rascal! (aside).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: That's very odd in a Privy Counsellor.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: It is by way of unbending, Sir— those great men must unbend. The lion must dandle the kid sometimes—the villain! (aside) I could tell you such tales of him. Hah! here his Lordship comes. Enter TIPPY. (Runs up to him) You shall have the other four hundred (apart).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Ah, ah, Sir Robert—what, I frightened you, did I?—I shan't trust you (apart to Fancourt).

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (giving him notes). Take it—here it is—the dog has been up to me this time (aside). Really, my Lord, it was not right to play on Sir Robert's credulity. He could not know but that you might be in earnest. But I must particularly insist on one thing, my Lord, that you do not speak of my character in such terms, though in jest. The jest which laughs away a man's reputation, is deadly poison administered in honey.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p:
Well, I won't—I won't. What do
you think I told him, Fancourt? I told him you lived at St. Giles's, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: No!—did you?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: He did indeed, ha, ha, ha! and that you were known in Bow-street, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Well, now I propose that we three jolly fellows, full of good humour, and lovers of fun, dash off to the Star and Garter—Champaigne and a song shall cheer our hearts, and set us above the cares of the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: With all my heart. Rattle glasses with a Lord—h—m—m— (with secret delight) it will be as good as dining with a Dutchess.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Come along, my little fellow; I'll introduce you to three Lords, and a Duke.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Here then we go—jest, mirth and pleasure inspire us!

div2.stage: They take Sir Robert between them and go off, wave their hats, and huzza.

div2.head: SCENE I.—TIPPY's Lodgings.
div2.stage: Enter Mrs. BULLRUSH, bringing in the Gown she wore in the first scene, work bag, &c.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bullrush.
sp.p: I'll take possession of his room myself, hang me if I don't! (sits down) here am I obliged to mend my gowns instead of buying new ones, because my lodgers won't pay me (threads a needle). No, no, Mr. Tippy— I'll fit you! I spoke to my neighbour Holdfast, yesterday; no one ever got out of his clutches yet, if once Holdfast touch'd him on the shoulder (works a little), Bless me! how my teeth torment me again (puts up her handkerchief) Betty! Betty—bring me a little brandy to hold in my mouth. I'll e'en go myself, she always brings such a drop! Exit.

div2.stage: Enter TIPPY, with a Letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p:
Yes, yes—tell them so— (speaking gaily) no, my artful sister, it won't do (reading) Wear the same disguise, and come as Miss Sally Martin. That is not possible—my landlady's maid, who used to lend me that smart dress, is off. What the devil can I do? to go there as a man, after having just been there as Lord Beechgrove, would be kicking down the milk pail with a vengeance! and yet to lose that sweet girl and her sweet estate— well, I can't go—I cannot go to Sir Robert's,
pos! (going out, runs against the table). What's this? my landlady's gown? gad it is! (opens it) if it fits me, I'll borrow it to personate Miss Sally Martin (puts it on). Hang me, but it does very well. She has often said, she would fit me, and now she has done it. And the smart bonnet too (puts it on). Freeze me, but I look as well as my landlady. Who—who the devil is this? (looking thro' the door) HOLDFAST, the Bailiff? whu! I am in the jaws of the lion!

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p:
Well, Madam, is Mr. Tippy come home? I have been watching for him the whole day (Tippy groans). I have been hunting him through every tavern, coffee-house, and gaming-house. I have been within three minutes of him, fifteen times. O! that I had but hold of his skirts! (Tippy groans). Alack-a-day, Mrs. Bullrush, still plagued with your teeth? (Tippy makes motions with his hand). Well, Madam, don't speak. If I once catch the young villain, we sha'n't part, (Tippy groans) I have one room double grated, and if he slides out of that, it must be thro' the keyhole. (Tippy groans, gets up, and puts Holdfast into his chair, making motions). Very well—I understand you. I'll stay here till you come back, Mrs. Bullrush; yes—I will. Exit. Tippy groaning. Poor creature! her teeth torment her like— what the dickens! why there's Mrs. Bullrush! (looking out) a trick! a trick! (bawling out) no— yes—'tis all in white! (looks scared) perhaps—
Mrs. Bullrush—Mrs. Bullrush! oh! (goes off trembling and frighten'd).

div2.head: SCENE II.—SIR SIMON ASGILL's Counting-Houses.—He is seated, looking melancholy and oppress'd.
div2.stage: PERKINS enters—he looks at SIR SIMON with great concern.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Sir, Sir—I pray you, Sir, speak!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Perkins! I have carried it too far. My boy can no where be found. Why did I hit on such a plan? I ought to have known that the sensibility of his heart, and the nobleness of his soul, could neither support seeing my distress, or living a useless member of society.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Sir, be comforted—it is not yet noon; perhaps the evening may bring us tidings.
A lady, Sir, desires to see you.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I can see no lady (petulantly).

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: She is particularly pressing, and requests to see you alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Who is she?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I have never seen her. Her servants are in mourning (a pause). Shall I conduct her to the drawing-room, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p:
No—if I must see her, bring her in here. The counting-house of an English merchant is respectable enough for the reception
of a prince;—I should not be ashamed to receive my king in it. (exit. Servant). Well, Perkins, you find the lady will have me alone—if I was in spirits to joke now, I could make myself merry at the fancy.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I hope your spirits and your jokes will soon come back. Faith, she's a pretty lady Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Your humble servant, Madam. (She curtseys, and seems confused). Pray sit down.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: I thank you. (He stands by her chair—she fans herself).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: You seem faint, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: No, Sir—no. In a moment I shall be better.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Not used, perhaps, to the bustle of driving thro' the City?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Not often. O! how shall I begin? my heart bursts with feeling, yet my tongue cannot give it utterance (aside).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Pray may I ask—what brought you here to-day?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: To-day, Sir—I came to-day (breathless) on a business so important—that— I scarcely know how to mention it, Sir—but— you have a nephew (looking on her fan).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I hope so, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: You have heard of Lady Horatia Horton,

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Heard of her—yes—I have heard of her!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: It is believ'd, Sir, that Mr. Asgill has some regard for her.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I hope not. My nephew, I believe, knows better than to regard such a gill-flirt.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Gill-flirt! Lady Horatia Horton, a gill-flirt.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Yes—the greatest gill-flirt I ever saw in my life.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (rising). Ah, he means Georgina, who saw him yesterday. I am so confused, I know not how to explain (aside).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: My nephew in love with a stone-cutter!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: A hewer of marble! why he may as well live in a quarry.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Monstrous! (aside).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Her study is a work-shop—her drawing-room a mason's saw-yard.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (aside). Insupportable! can this be the uncle of Sidney Asgill?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: There she chissels out womens' faces with young serpents hanging in drop curls, by way of a new fashion'd tete.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (in great warmth). Nay, I can bear it no longer! Sir, this more than gothic ignorance, is a disgrace to the age in which we live, and to your own situation. The head of the beautiful MEDUSA is amongst the wonders of the art. O! the more than martial skill, which could make BEAUTY horrible!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Hey! The dumb lady cured! what is she crazy?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
At the same place you saw
(with enthusiasm) the touching NIOBE, mourning over her children;—the light ATALANTA flying from her lover—the graceful GANYMEDE caught up to Olympus for his beauty, did none of those strike ye? none of those awaken your adoration for the sublime art,—for SCULPTURE! whose long enduring beauties bid defiance to time, and laugh at ages!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon
sp.p: (singing). "I am mad Bess, believe me."

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Your coarseness, Sir, is hardly to be borne! how different from yours is the mind of your nephew! he has sat whole hours admiring those wonders of the art, and patiently watching the strokes of the chissel, which presumed at distant imitation.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: It is the first instance of his folly I ever heard. I thought Sidney had been a different sort of a man.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: I suppose you have been employing your talents to the more exalted purposes of importing verdigrease, and blubber, and in making monopolies.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Monopolies! no, Madam, never! there is one monopoly, and only one, to which I give my assent;—may the posterity of Englishmen continue to monopolize this little island, as long as the sea fills its channel, or the winds blow upon its rocks! have you any commission for me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Commission—Sir—I came— I intended—it was my design—no, Sir, I have no commission.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p:
When you have, Madam, I shall be happy to see you again, but I really have not
had time to read my letters, which I must beg to do directly. Order the lady's carriage.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Sir—I really feel myself so insulted that—perhaps, Sir—but no matter. Perhaps you are right—yes, Sir, you are very right (goes out weeping, yet with dignity).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Perkins! come in Perkins! (he enters) why I was never so stunn'd in my life. Here's a woman comes on pretence to speak about my nephew, and then begins some gibberish about sculpture,—and talks of Ganymede, and Atalanta, and Olympus, and such vile trash as lads learn out of Ovid; books, that if I was a member of parliament, I'd bring in a bill to make it felony for any bookseller to vend.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: It would do you more honor, Sir, than any canal bill, bill for roads, or any other improvement that was ever brought before the House.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Hah, Mr. Conway, what news— what news? (running towards him).

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Alas! none, Sir. I have follow'd our poor Sidney by every possible clue that I could obtain; but he has pass'd away like a vapour— not a trace remains (sighing).

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: O! fye—O! fye. (shaking his head with a melancholy air).

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I suppose Lady Horatia Horton has been here to make enquiries.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Lady Horatia Horton. She stept into her carriage as I came up to the gate— but she seem'd to be weeping, so I avoided her.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Bless me, Sir—there has been some mistake. (to Sir Simon)

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I don't know—I am all in a wood! why, was that lady in mourning, Lady Horatia Horton?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Why 'tis quite a different person from her I saw, yesterday, at her house.

sp.speaker: Conway
sp.p: (smiling). O yes, ha, ha—I have heard about that. The lady you saw was quite a different person.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Gad I hope I shall never have the luck to see her again.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I can't endure her.

sp.speaker: Conway
sp.p: (angrily). Sir! not endure her? why, she is the most charming of her sex. That lady, Sir, has more sweetness of disposition, more playful innocence of heart, and more beauty than half the women in the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I hope I may form a different opinion, Mr. Conway.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: No, Sir—no man shall form a different opinion—or if he does, he must take care to conceal it in my presence.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I shall take no care, Sir. I will use the freedom of an Englishman to speak all I think of you, and of every man, and of every woman too. How dared she assume a character she was not?—how dared she say such things of my nephew to my face?

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: Sir! whatever that lady says, I make myself answerable for.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: O, Gentlemen, let me entreat you! —you will both be sorry—you have been both too warm.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: I advise you to persuade Sir Simon that he has been so!—I shall expect his apology.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon
sp.p: (staring). Why, what's in the wind to-day, Perkins! I affront every one who comes near me, without designing it, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Your temper has been a little ruffled, Sir; you are sore about Mr. Asgill.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Sore indeed! and my heart will be sore soon, as well as my temper, if I do not hear of him, But about this Lady Horatia— 'tis very odd! what could bring her here? perhaps she came to tell me some news. I think I will go to her.

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: It would be best, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: I certainly will—after change. But I hope I shall not see her marble monsters again—they'll put me out of sorts if I do. What a taste!

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Dear Sir, any taste is better than no taste, and a lady who employs her thoughts and her chissel on works of art, is, at least, not idle; and, therefore, as Doctor Johnson says, not in the way of being wicked. Exeunt.

head.stage: SCENE changes to SIR ROBERT's Drawing-Room.

sp.speaker: Humphrey.
sp.p: Why, what a noddy have I been, to take this strapper always for a girl! (aside).

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: What is the oaf grinning at? do as I bid you—tell Mrs. Jenny her friend Miss Sally Martin is here. Humprey goes out, making faces. Gad, I had a good run. I was hardly safe in the hack, before the bailiff and my landlady were in pursuit.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: O! Jack, I am so—

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Hush! come to the point. I am in danger every moment that I stay. What progress have you made with your mistress! What is to be done?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why what is to be done, is to get her any way into your power—once get her to your lodgings, and a marriage must follow.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (sneeringly). Good!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: I have prevail'd on her to go with me alone, to the famous wax-work. She knows not where it is, so I'll bring her in a hack to your lodgings; and then—mercy! here she comes—what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Do!—upon my soul she's a sweet creature! I hope she won't detect the Connoiseur, in petticoats.

div2.stage: GEORGINA enters—TIPPY bows very low— recovers himself, and curtseys.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Bless me, Jenny—who is this?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: A— stranger Ma'am—a lady that. Did you not say, Madam, that you ran into the hall to avoid some gentlemen who were rude to you? (to Tippy) and then, Miss, that blundering fellow, Humphrey, brought him up—I mean brought the lady up here.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am, he brought me up here. Really a modest woman can hardly walk the streets, men are so impertinent. One gentleman seiz'd my hand; d—n you, Sir, says I— I mean I said, bless me, Sir, I beg you won't be rude.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: A very odd lady, Jenny!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Curse the petticoats! Madam I scorn to impose on you—no, Madam, I have a soul above it—I am not a lady. I put on this disguise to procure admission here, that I might tell you how I adore you, Madam (kneeling) my passion for you is so great, that if you do not look on me with pity—if you do not listen to me with compassion— (Jenny shrieks).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: A lady at my daughter's feet! (Tippy starts up) some great favour sure she is asking. What did you shriek for?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p:
Shriek, Sir—O, Sir, the poor lady —she was saying as how that she had a cruel husband—I never heard of such a villain! and she was deploring Miss to speak to you in the
affair, for you know him. He seems a most sweet young fellow, Ma'am, it would be great pity to betray him! (aside)

sp.speaker: Georgina
sp.p: (to herself). The Savoyard! O, I remember all at this moment!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Do I know your husband, Ma'am! Pray do not wheel round in this manner— there's nothing shameful in having a bad husband—if there were, few married women would care to shew their faces.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (in a shrill voice). O, Sir, I should die with confusion. (still keeping his back to Sir Robert).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, is the fault all your husband's?

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: O, entirely, Sir;—my behaviour to him is quite angelic.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I dare say your face is angelic, if one could but see it (still wheeling to get a peep at her). Perhaps you live a little too gaily for him, poor man!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Not at all! I am a pattern of prudence —generally at home by four in the morning. Charming creature! pity my distress! (in his own voice to Georgina).

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Pray Ma'am turn, and shew yourself to my Papa, and if you tell him the same affecting story you began to me—

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: (apart). Nay pray, Ma'am, do not betray him! how can you have the heart? he would die rather than do you an ill turn. Did you observe what teeth he has?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Sweet lady, speak! a design so pure, and eloquence so irresistable, will affect Sir Robert as it ought.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Sweet lady turn round! gad, there's some fudge here—I am sure there is. Sir Robert take my advice—look in the lady's face.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (goes to her). Nay, Madam, 'tis in vain. I will see your bright eyes, or never — (Tippy trips up Sir Robert, and then attempts to run off).

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: A Thalastris, by Jupiter! (seizing Tippy) nay, I will have a peep, spite of your dexterity, Miss! (Tippy struggles) come, to the right about! by Heavens this must be a man— Sir Robert, I smell a rat (turns him). Zounds! what Tippy! I am a bit of a Marplot here. This comes of your entrusting your friends by halves (apart).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: What it is a man, then! I thought it was the most robust damsel I had ever met with.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Get out of the house (pushing him). You might well hide your face! get out, or I will make you shew it at the Old Bailey (drives him out).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Who is he?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Oh, a fellow who lives by his wits; one whose stock in trade is all in the pia mater. (touching his forehead).

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (to Georgina). How came he here in this disguise? where have you seen him? I insist on knowing the truth.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: She seems sadly puzzled—the girl has been taught that 'tis a sin to tell lies.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why don't you speak, Georgina? come be bold! your prompter I see is at your elbow.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Pray speak, Miss. Say it is your staymaker. (aside)

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Yes, I will speak. I assure you, Sir, (taking her father's hand) I never saw that person till now; but a circumstance which, I believe, must relate to him, has struck my recollection, and makes me shudder.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: What is it, child?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Sir—I—yesterday, Sir, I had my fortune told.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Pho!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, mine was no common fortune-teller; she was certainly a well-bred woman in disguise.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Why, what did she say to you?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: She told me that two men—two most unprincipled monsters, had laid a plot for my destruction (he starts). Her disguise was that of a Savoyard, with music.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Whu! (aside.)

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I remember you ran through the library to go to listen to her.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Pray—pray, Madam, what sort of a person was this pretended Savoyard?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: An agreeable little woman, with eyes full of intelligence, and manners full of good sense.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Yes, it was my devil, I see clearly. (aside.)

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: This seeming lady is probably one of the two men I had notice of, who introduced himself here, to carry on designs which make me tremble.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
I believe you do, my dear. I never saw you so grave, nor heard you talk so discreetly before; a little fright has done you
good. May you never cease to tremble, Georgina, when you recollect the hazards of this hour!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: You, Jenny, have always nourish'd my follies, and cherish'd my absurdities; I will never hold communication with you more. Go directly to the housekeeper, receive your wages, and leave my father's house. Begone!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why, she can never mean this in earnest; this must be all fudge before her father. (goes hesitatingly.)

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: O! that every misguided daughter would retrieve her errors before it be too late, and, like you, take shelter in the arms of a fond and forgiving father! (embracing her.) My dear Georgina, I wish thou hadst either a mother, or a husband!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: A most edifying scene, this! (aside.)

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Mr. Fancourt, you know who this fellow is.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Not absolutely know him—I have seen him; and I will trace him out, Sir, if it be possible. And I'll find your little Savoyard too, Madam; your pretty fortune-teller; it shall go hard but I'll meet with her! Exit.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: O! I wish he may discover her, for I shall cherish burning gratitude towards her, to the last hour of my existence! My dear Sir, I feel like one of our little Welch kids at home, trembling on the brink of a monstrous precipice, when its sond parent appears, and guides back its feeble steps, to crop the flow'ry herbage in safety.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon
sp.p: (entering). Madam, your most obedient. I did not know that you were Lady Horatia Horton this morning; so I came to apologize, and all that.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: An unncessary trouble, Sir. (coldly.)

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Not at all, Madam, not at all. If I offend, I am always ready to make amends. A little gipsey yesterday took your name, and railed at Sidney; I could not bear it.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: And was it therefore, Sir, that you insulted my art? Was it therefore that you laughed at, and abused my—

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Your monsters, Madam. O! keep clear of them, whatever you do! Don't talk of them!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Why, is this possible?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Madam, this life is too short to squander time upon trisles; so, let us come to the point! I am told that you have a great regard for my nephew, and I love and admire you for it; talk of him, and we shall agree to the end of the chapter.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: The person who told you so, Sir, took an unwarrantable freedom.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Why, you told me so yourself. Would any lady fly into the city, to talk to a cross old fellow about his nephew, if she had not set her heart upon him? Pho! pho! that spoke your sentiments pretty plainly.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (weeping with vexation). O dear! I tell you, I hate your nephew?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Do you? O, you woman! You downright woman! I see how it is. When he was rich, you loved him; when you looked forward to fine equipage, splendour and expence, you acknowledged his merits; but now that you have heard he is poor, you despise him. O! woman, woman!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (with heat). Sir, it is false. You injure me in every part of your opinion. When he was rich, he never knew that he had caused a tender thought in me; it was only his poverty that made my passion break out without disguise. It was his distress that made me feel, and acknowledge I adore him.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: What, then, you do love him?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia
sp.p: (much confused). What have I said?

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: What you ought never to recal. Speak on; you now talk like a sensible woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Well, then, receive my full confession. You, his second father! Mr. Asgill has twined himself into my soul; his poverty has endeared him to me a thousand times. Go, Sir, search him out; bring him from his retreat, and tell him, that Horatia Horton knows no value in wealth, but in the pleasure of dividing it with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Huzza, huzza! here's a woman for ye! Madam, he is not poor. I'll put down for Asgill thousand for thousand, as long as you please, and when I die, leave him a plumb!

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p:
It was all a sagacious trick of
mine. I wanted to try if the dear lad really loved me, and if he possessed real worth of soul. Sentiments, truly noble, he often uttered; but noble sentiments are uttered by scoundrels, who do not possess one feeling, which, if brought to the touchstone, would not disgrace humanity.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Mr. Asgill not poor! (pausing.) Nay, then I understand the flimsy contrivance. A pitiful plot, to force me to reveal a secret, which I chose to bury in the bottom of my heart. Presuming! (haughtily.) Make me a dupe! Now, Sir, know that your nephew rich, and your nephew poor, are two distinct persons. I detest his art, and recal all I have said. The rich Mr. Asgill, I shall teach myself henceforward to despise. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Whu! Why, what's in the wind now? Upon my soul, I would rather cast up the most intricate account of compound interest, than attempt to calculate what will please a woman. Refuse a man because he is rich!!!

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: O, Sir! I followed you here without your permission, my tidings are so good, Mr. Asgill is found.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Ah, Perkins, I saw it in thy eyes, without a word. Thou art an honest fellow, Perkins (squeezing his hand). In what street or alley was he found?

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p:
Street, Sir! A very wide, and a very turbulent street. You will be surprised to hear. I employed my own brother in the business. He traced him last night down to
Portsmouth, where he had entered himself on board a man of war before the mast!

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: Nay, come, Sir, he is returned.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Is he come back?

sp.speaker: Perkins.
sp.p: William prevailed on him; put him into a chaise and four, and brought him back to his own lodgings.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Come along, come along! It shall be the best day William ever saw. Exit.

div2.head: SCENE—FANCOURT's.
div2.stage: Enter FANCOURT, followed by Mrs. FANCOURT.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (carelessly). Yes—no, my dear— yes—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: I hope you have been well amused since yesterday, Mr. Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Perfectly so, Mrs. Fancourt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: You shou'd let me know when you do not mean to return. It is rather unpleasant to sit up all night watching.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: O! you can find amusement.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: You are fond of masquerading, you know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: I do not understand you; I never was at more than one masquerade, nor ever formed a wish to repeat it.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: And the habit you then wore, I remember, was that of a Savoyard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt
sp.p: (starting). It was.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: And did you then tell fortunes too?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt
sp.p: (aside). I die with fear. Surely I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (seizing her hand), Come, tell me, Madam, have you not lately repeated the scene of the Savoyard?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Sir! O! he will have no mercy on me! (trembling.)

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: But, why need I ask? I know you have. That fortune-telling was a pretty thought, my dear; but did it occur to you to tell your own fortune? Did you foretel to yourself your own fate on the discovery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Alas! I know too well I must expect all that malice and revenge can inspire; but if I have saved an innocent from destruction, and turned away the arrow which was about to pierce the heart of her benevolent father, I am resigned.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Who are you, who enter with so little ceremony into my apartments?

sp.speaker: 1st Man.
sp.p: What, Master Fancourt, don't you remember us? Mayhap you'll know this? (taking a constable's staff from his pocket.)

sp.speaker: 2d Man,
sp.p: And this? (drawing forth another.)

sp.speaker: 1st Man.
sp.p: Here is a coach waiting below with two of our companions; so the quicker you are, the better.

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (pale and trembling). This sudden surprise has overpowered me. On whose account do I see you?

sp.speaker: 1st Man.
sp.p: You'll know that in proper time. I never likes to answer trogatories.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Where am I going?

sp.speaker: 2d Man.
sp.p: You'll see when we arrive.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Wherever it is, I will not stir without this woman. She shall accompany me wherever I go.

sp.speaker: 2d Man.
sp.p: Why, you have a very fond husband, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Not so; but he is my husband: I therefore follow without a murmur.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Go first; I will not leave you in the room? Exit Mrs. Fancourt. Come, gentlemen, let us follow the lady. Bear witness that I am a polite husband to the last. Exit.

div2.head: SCENE—Sir ROBERT's Drawing-room.
div2.stage: He enters with a troubled air.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: A sad, sad slut! Why, what a town this is! A stranger, like me, should go about in leading-strings. Plotters, deceivers in every corner of it. Whether the people one associates with, are what they appear to be, or whether it may not be all one universal masquerade, there is no guessing. (Goes and opens the door.) Come—come forth! JENNY comes out, and walks to the front. He looks at her earnestly. Now art thou a woman, or a griffin, prithee tell me?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p:
Dear Sir, I can tell you no more than I have; I have confess'd every thing; and, on
my bended knees, I ask for mercy. (kneeling) I am not a griffin, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Get up; your flummery of kneeling has no effect. How far I shall have mercy on a wretch, who plann'd the dishonour of my child, I shall consider. I have never met with so atrocious a jade, since the year I was high sheriff for the county. Retire. Your brother, my Lord Beechgrove, approaches.

sp.speaker: Jenny
sp.p: (starting up). I care not that for your sneers! (snapping her fingers.) I'll teach you, my old gentleman, what it is for sixty to have the impudence to slight five and twenty. I have wasted as many tender blushes, soft ogles, and enamoured glances on your shrivell'd chops, as might have fubdued half the gallant soldiers in the allied armies; but I'll be up with you yet!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: O, a hussy! What a sad thing it is for a young man, like me, to have wanted gallantry. TIPPY enters. My Lord, I am your lordship's most obedient. Why, you have made great haste in undressing, my lord; you are a quick hand at a toilette, I see.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (looking aghast). Hey!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I did not exactly know, at first, how to direct to you, to summon your lordship hither, but your sister, the lady Jenny, help'd me out—Mr. Tippy!

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (aside). The devil!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p:
Pray, when do you publish, Sir?
Your life must be an amusing one. Put me down as a subscriber.

sp.speaker: Tippy
sp.p: (aside). Nay, since all is out, I'll brazen it. I'll put you down for something else, Sir, when I publish.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Be assured the public shall not want the story of Taffy, the Welch knight; who came up a wool-gathering from Glamorganshire, after Begums, Nansooks, and Patna-rice.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Well, well, I feel that I deserve this, so I take it patiently. Here comes more company; some of your friends, my lord.

div2.stage: FANCOURT enters, Mrs. FANCOURT, and Constables. Sir ROBERT nods to the Constables, who retire.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: So, Tippy—all is up!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: Faith, I think, all is down—we have rather a tumble.

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: Be it so! I have aim'd high; resolved if I did fall, to fall from an eminence. Well, Sir Knight, you'll give us a bottle of Champaigne at parting, and let us be merry once again! You thought it celestial happiness, last night, to get tipsey with a lord, and hear him roar out an indecent catch. Do you remember, Tippy, how he oped his mouth, and how his eyes water'd with joy? Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I can bear all this, for I really have been so preposterously ridiculous, that, I think, I deserve even more than your malice can suggest.

sp.speaker: Fancourt,
sp.p:
"I say, SNAPPER, we must have him on our side." Ha, ha, ha! "The old
scoundrel had like to have undone us (sips). He is a great fool, but he is related to all the ap Morgans, and ap Shoneses in the county." Ha, ha, ha! That was well, I never hook'd a gudgeon with so little trouble in my life!
It is, it is herself! My charming Savoyard, how I rejoice to see you! You are my mother, sister, friend—

sp.speaker: Fancourt
sp.p: (going up to Mrs. Fancourt). You, Madam, to whose officiousness my friend and I, owe our disgrace—you shall be rewarded. Now listen (seizing her hand), for I am going to plunge a dagger into your heart—you are not my wife. (flinging away her hand.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Not your wife?

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: No. Your affectation and delicacy would not permit you to be married in a Church, you may remember, so I took advantage of your folly, and brought a man, who was never priest till that moment.

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: It is very true, and I am he; it was I who married you. (bowing low)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Can it be possible? Do I hear right? Am I releas'd from obedience to a man whom I abhor? Is it no longer my duty to associate with vice? Is it no longer my fate to eat the bread of wickedness? O, blissful moment!

sp.speaker: Tippy.
sp.p: I am surprised you feel so; he is a very good kind of young man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: O! welcome poverty and want!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p:
Never! Your fate is united to
mine. You are my mother, sister, friend! I must quit you a few moments, for Lady Horatia Horton has sent Mr. Conway for me; but I will leave you in my own apartment. My father's roof is your everlasting protection!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: This is, indeed, a stroke! Is she to be happy?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: Yes, that she shall, if my protection can make her so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fancourt.
sp.p: Unhappy man, farewell! The ruin of my peace and fortune I can forgive! O! whilst innocence and friendship invite me to repose, may you find it in repentance.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: And now, gentlemen, leave my house this moment, or the next you shall be returned into the hands of the constables. Go! turn out upon the world!

sp.speaker: Fancourt.
sp.p: We will turn out upon the world; so let the world beware! Come, Tippy, the field before us is a wide one—let us erect our banners! Talents are our armed forces, with which we encounter Vanity and Foll. Where-ever they appear, we wage war. Allons! (to Tippy.) Be of good heart, my boy! The foe is numerous, but weak. Conquest and pillage are our own! They go off.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert
sp.p: (looking after them). I am glad you are off! These gentlemen have given me some amusement, together with some experience, and it has cost me only one thousand pounds —a cheap bargain! Exit.

div2.head: SCENE—Lady HORATIA's Drawing-room.
div2.stage: Lady HORATIA enters, accompanied by Lady CHARLOTTE.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: No—no—Adieu to low spirits for ever! My heart is as light as the feather in your hair; I know all; Mr. Conway has told me every thing; there was no plot on me! No, my Asgill has proved himself in the hour of trial, as noble, as delicate, as brave as my fancy had always painted him.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: Well, happiness is a most becoming thing; it gives fire and expression to every feature. But can it be possible that Mr. Asgill should design to serve as a sailor? I thought the party with whom he—

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Mention parties at an hour like this! O! let such distinctions melt into air, and be obliterated for ever! Let every party join hand and heart to save this country, and to cherish its BLESSED CONSTITUTION!

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: See, here comes Georgina, playing the little tyrant with her enamour'd Conway.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: I protest I will not hear such things, Mr. Conway. (snatches away her hand) Why will you teaze me thus? Lady Horatia, I beg you chide him; for he has been talking nonsense to me all the way in your coach.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
It will give him more pleasure if you chide him. Nay, I will be more
malicious still, spite of your frowns; I absolutely will tell you— Georgina puts her hand to Lady Horatia's mouth. You do not hate him.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: O! that sound is bliss to me!

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Ah, but I am sure I do not love him.

sp.speaker: Conway.
sp.p: How do you know, angel?

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Why, I never keep wakeful about you, nor ever dream about you. And I do not grow pale, like Miss Gwatkin; and I eat my breakfast with pleasure, and I dine very well; and if I do not see you for a whole day together, I only think—well, to-morrow I shall be more lucky.

sp.speaker: Conway
sp.p: (in rapture). Enough, enough— more than I hoped. On these terms I am content to bind my fate to yours. Such artless candour renders you enchanting.

sp.speaker: Georgina.
sp.p: Well, then—but do not speak to my papa about it for whole week. Bless me— here's old Simon. (runs to the top, followed by Conway.)

div2.stage: Enter Sir SIMON, with ASGILL, in a sailor's dress.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Here, Madam, I have brought ye your sailor; and if you do not receive him with kindness, and welcome him back with your whole soul, you are no woman for me!

sp.speaker: Asgill
sp.p: (rushing to her feet). Adored mistress of my heart! am I welcome?

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p:
Welcome! O, Asgill, there are characters so high, so noble, that to be chained in by common decorums, would be to have no taste for excellence, and my heart
bounds with disdain from such frozen rules! I, who have hitherto treated you with coldness, almost bordering on disdain, now declare, in the presence of my friends, that I am proud to make you master of my fate; that I feel exalted in having it in my power to confer happiness on you.

sp.speaker: Asgill
sp.p: (rising). O! woman unequall'd!— Blessed be the hour in which you believed me poor and undone! Sir Simon has been feeding my soul with exstacy.

sp.speaker: Lady Horatia.
sp.p: Mr. Asgill, you must, indeed, love Sir Simon; but I know not how I shall set about doing so; he hates the arts; he thinks there is nothing dignified in sculpture; he hears, without veneration, the names of Phidias, and Michael Angelo.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: Come, come, Madam, throw away your chisel and your marble blocks, and set about making a good wife. That ART is the noblest pride of an Englishwoman.

sp.speaker: Lady Charlotte.
sp.p: Lady Horatia, you are all smiles! I declare I should not so easily have forgiven a man (looking on Asgill) who could fly from me to the boisterous ocean, and prove such insensibility to beauty and love.

sp.speaker: Asgill.
sp.p:
Misjudge me not! I, insensible to beauty, and to love! O! my glowing soul confesses their force, and adores their power. Yet the enthusiasm which seized me, when I trod the deck of the Victory, can never be chill'd! In the glorious tars around me, valour, intrepidity, heroism, shone forth with all their fires; they flashed through my heart! And, I swear, that should my country need my assistance, I will again resume the trowsers,
and sail before the mast, wherever she bids her cannon roar, or her proud pendants fly. (Advancing forward) Ah! repose on us! And when you look on the gallant spirits, who do honour to this habit, let every fear subside; for, whilst the sea flows, and English sailors are themselves, ENGLAND MUST BE THE MISTRESS OF THE GLOBE!

div1.head: EPILOGUE, MISS WALLIS.
div1.l: THROUGH five long Acts—a pretty decent swing—
I've been a giddy, tender, harmless thing;
Light as a feather, in the morn of May,
Borne by the perfum'd breath of blue-eyed day.
Nor have I yet thrown by my studied part,
GEORGINA, still I am, in garb, and heart—
GEORGINA humbly stands again before ye,
Of gratitude so full!—she half adores ye.
It puzzles me to guess, when Conway's wife,
On what sweet plan to form my married life:
My heart beats high to think how I shall flash,
Pre-eminent, and bold, like Lady Dash.
Reflection ne'er to me shall be a damper,
My curricle I'll drive—on horseback scamper—
Keep Pharo Banks—take the long odds at races,
And know the knowing ones, in all their paces;
Lounge at Newmarket in the betting-rooms,
And prate to Lady Harriet—and my grooms.
But whilst I thus blaze on, in Folly's road,
And profligate, forsake my blest abode—
Where is my husband's peace?—his honour—where?
Who shall his lonely hours console, and share?
O! the black prospect scares my trembling art,
And from the headlong precipice I start.
Dear wedded happiness! my soul is thine,
My pride shall be, in thy mild paths to shine—
My CONWAY's temperate joys I'll make my own,
And his felicity my life shall crown;
With him through Pleasure's paths I'll sometimes roam,
But still my first enjoyment, shall be HOME.
The Household Gods ten thousand graces wear.
Nor stoop to borrow tinsel'd, foreign glare—
Yet never shall your Household Deities frown,
Though you should steal an hour, to see—THE TOWN!
